The ministry also found other items in the bag, such as another wallet, a sum of $563, three sunglasses, a female wrist watch, and "brownish stuff looking like hashish."
The ministry said that security forces "succeeded in targeting" a criminal gang near New Cairo area, which specialized in "impersonating policemen" for purposes of kidnapping and robbing foreigners living in Egypt.
The ministry killed all four members of the gang, who had engaged in a gunfire exchange with the police during their arrest.
The ministry identified the killed suspects as Tarek Abdel Fattah, 52 years old, along with his 26-year-old son Saad Abdel Fattah, Mostafa Bakr, 60, and Salah Ali, 40.
The police said the men were driving a minibus as they neared a security checkpoint, opening fire on security forces.
A fifth body, unidentified, was found in the minibus, in addition to an automatic rifle, a gun, an electric shock, and forged police cards carrying the badge of the Interior Ministry.
The police raided the apartment of the first suspect's sister, where they also found his wife.
The ministry said the sister confessed to her brother's crimes, and after searching the apartment, they found the belongings of Regeni, and others, which she also admitted were stolen by her brother.
The gang was responsible for the robbery of more than $20,000 from nine Egyptians and foreign citizens, including an Italian citizen named David K. and a Portuguese citizen named Carlos M.
The ministry thanked the Italian investigative delegation working on Regeni's case in Egypt for "its efforts and cooperation."
Regeni, 28, was found dead in a ditch along the Cairo-Alexandria Desert Road on 3 February, nine days after his disappearance.
Italy widely denounced the killing of Regeni, demanding prompt and transparent investigations and the perpetuators to be held accountable.

Turkish and Israeli officials first met openly in December 2015 and reached a preliminary agreement to normalize relations.
During a meeting held in early February 2016, Turkish and Israeli officials discussed easing rather than lifting the blockade of Gaza.
3645c2d8502efaa36a88907a7e134e19:
Talks on normalizing relations between Turkey and Israel continue.
Turkey and Israel have achieved serious results during the talks.
Removal of the Gaza Strip's blockade by Israel is one of the important issues in the talks.
Turkey and Israel had private talks before.
Relations between Israel and Turkey deteriorated after the Freedom Flotilla incident in 2010.
Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan said Israel should apologize for the Freedom Flotilla incident, pay compensation to the families of those killed and end the blockade of the Gaza Strip.
da00b6f0eb8adf28f09f3e80f78ce3d2:
The ongoing talks on the normalisation of relations between Turkey and Israel have reached the final stage.
Turkey and Israel will sign an agreement to normalise relations after a final settlement is reached on the two final conditions set by Turkey: lifting the siege on Gaza and the compensation being paid to the families of those killed on the Mavi Marmara.
Turkish-Israeli relations were strained in 2010 when Israeli military forces assaulted international activists, including Turks, who were on board the Mavi Marmara ship.
Turkey has set a number of conditions on the return of relations with Israel, including receiving an apology for the killing of Turkish activists, paying compensation to the victims' families, in addition to lifting the siege on the Gaza Strip.
The pending point that still hinders reaching a settlement is the Turkish condition to lift the blockade on Gaza, which Israel rejects.
Israeli newspapers have said that Egypt is putting pressure on Tel Aviv to prevent any Turkish role in the Gaza Strip.
Egypt refuses to open the Rafah border crossing to Palestinians.
db3287fe6c185e2e8463066f352064fe:
Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan announced that Israel and Turkey's negotiating teams will meet again in mid-May to try to reach a reconciliation deal.
Turkey and Israel are discussing the establishment of humanitarian projects in Gaza relating to electricity and water, as part of the negotiations surrounding Turkish demands toward "lifting the embargo" on Gaza.
Turkey offered to send a ship, anchored in Israel's Ashdod port, to provide electricity for Gaza to help cope with the Strip's severe energy crisis.
Israel offered the establishment of a power plant within Gaza, carried out between Turkey and Germany, as an alternative project.
Israel is also positive toward Turkey's proposal to address Gaza's water problem through water desalination plants or wells.
The Israeli and Turkish negotiating teams met three weeks ago in London.
The Foreign Ministry in Ankara announced after that round that progress had been made in closing the gap toward reaching a reconciliation agreement.
One of the main issues, however, is the lack of consensus on Israel's demand to stop military command from Hamas' headquarters in Istanbul.
e08e73ac07d22ac17b6463e43e5a2a7a:
Canada's foreign affairs minister Stephane Dion called on the United Nations to review the appointment of Michael Lynk as the U.N. Human Rights Council’s special rapporteur on human rights in Palestine due to Lynk's history of anti-Israel bias.
Canada's opposition Conservative Party also called for Lynk to be disqualified from the position based on his past statements on Israel.
Jewish advocacy groups in Canada denounced Lynk as having a long and public history of anti-Israel bias, including signing anti-Israel petitions, calling for Israel to be prosecuted for war crimes, accusing Israel of ethnic cleansing, addressing conferences promoting one binational state, and serving as a leader of a group that promotes Israeli Apartheid Week.
The Geneva-based group UN Watch said the council’s choice of Lynk was “a travesty of justice.”
c7caa60db25b947412fa3522d8c5f28e:
The United Nations Human Rights Council (UNHRC) passed a resolution obligating its commissioner to assemble a database of business entities involved in Israeli settlements in disputed territories.
The resolution does not include an enforcement mechanism, but it is likely to cause serious trouble for businesses involved in Israeli settlements.
The resolution encourages the Israeli public to forget that the international legal system considers all settlements illegal and in violation of international conventions.
Companies will be exposed to calls for a boycott, severed business connections, and legal action if they are included in the database.
The resolution is legal and permitted, and may even be included in the criteria for receiving a "social business" label.
The list of Israeli companies working in the settlements is long and includes most of the business sector.
The UNHRC has a long history of one-sided and anti-Semitic acts against Israel.
Israel's foreign policy has failed to erase the legal and political peculiarities of the settlements.
The current Israeli government finds it difficult to understand the view that the settlements are illegal.
Israel is coming to terms with a practical separation between Israel and the settlements.
19c23e63276fd8e8df6523d817a43548:
Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas is working to stop Palestinian knife attacks and other street violence against Israel.
Abbas has offered to meet Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to rekindle peace efforts.
Abbas's security forces search pupils' bags in schools for knives and have found 70 boys and girls carrying knives.
Abbas and Israel coordinate security in the occupied West Bank.
Netanyahu says he is open to renewing talks, but Abbas says the onus is on Netanyahu.
Since October, Palestinian stabbings, car-rammings and gun ambushes have killed 28 Israelis and two U.S. citizens.
Abbas is willing to take action against Palestinians that Israeli intelligence deems a threat.
Netanyahu has said he would favor the creation of a Palestinian state as long as Israel’s terms are met.
Whether Abbas could vouchsafe the Gaza Strip is in doubt, as it is under the de facto control of armed Hamas Islamists who oppose permanent coexistence with Israel.
Netanyahu has been hazy about whether he would remove Jewish settlements in the West Bank to make way for the Palestinians.
bfacbf4bf5e6c35be8d086dd02a228c1:
New Zealand's former prime minister Helen Clark announced her candidacy to be the next UN secretary-general.
Clark aims to become the first woman to lead the world body.
New Zealand Prime Minister John Key formally put forward Clark as the country's candidate.
Clark imposed diplomatic sanctions on Israel in 2004 after New Zealand convicted two Israelis of attempting to illegally obtain New Zealand passports.
Clark demanded an apology and an explanation from Israel.
Ties were resumed in 2005 after Jerusalem issued an apology.
Clark is today the administrator of the United Nations Development Program (UNDP).
The search for a successor to Ban Ki-moon comes at a time of high anxiety in global affairs.
Other than Clark, seven candidates including three women are vying for the top job.
2580a8bcdb7e88f97b0e4302b3a5a4b5:
The United Nations (UN) was founded in 1945 to replace the League of Nations and promote international cooperation and world peace.
The UN's charter outlines its purpose to maintain international peace and security, develop friendly relations among nations, achieve international cooperation in solving global problems, and harmonize the actions of nations.
The UN has made significant contributions to global peace, including the 1947 vote for the partitioning of British Mandate Palestine, which led to the re-birth of Israel as a modern nation.
However, the UN has been criticized for its disproportionate focus on Israel, with more resolutions passed against Israel than the rest of the world combined.
The UN's obsession with demonizing Israel is evident in its resolutions, conferences, and statements, including the recent claim that Israel is the number one country violating women's human rights.
The UN's actions have been accused of promoting violence, lies, and murders, such as funding tree planting to honor terrorists.
The UN's anti-Israel bias is attributed to the large number of Arab/Muslim member nations who vote against Israel at every opportunity.
Despite Israel's efforts to treat Palestinians fairly, the UN's negative portrayal of Israel continues, leading to accusations of antisemitism.
ffff6934f2891c431ffcbdbeaab57539:
The Palestinian Authority is circulating a draft resolution to U.N. Security Council members condemning Israeli building in the West Bank and Jerusalem.
P.A. President Mahmoud Abbas reportedly hopes to bring the resolution to a vote in two weeks.
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Abbas “is taking a step that will push negotiations further away.”
The Security Council last voted on such a resolution in February 2011, which was approved but vetoed by the United States.
The draft resolution states that the settlements are an obstacle to peace and Israel must stop construction.
The resolution also condemns settler violence against Palestinians.
Abbas will be arriving in New York on April 22 to attend the planned vote.
Abbas is also expected to make diplomatic visits to Paris, Berlin and Moscow to build support for the resolution.
eeb0450536070b323456606548854356:
Palestinian officials have circulated a draft resolution among UNSC members condemning Israeli construction in the West Bank and East Jerusalem and calling for its halt.
The resolution also condemns Israeli settler violence.
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said that the resolution will push negotiations farther away.
The resolution is moderate compared to the one put forth by the Palestinians five years ago, as it doesn't call for the establishment of a Palestinian state or for international protection.
The Palestinians are planning to test the outgoing Obama administration with this draft, after the US vetoed a similarly-worded resolution in 2011.
It is believed that the resolution was moderated to make it harder for the US to use its veto power.
Washington has recently intensified its rhetoric opposing construction in the West Bank.
The final decision of whether or not to put the resolution to a vote at the UN Security Council hasn't been decided yet.
Abbas is expected to arrive in New York in two weeks for a three-day visit, in order to sign a climate change treaty.
The Palestinian Authority believes that Abbas will put forth the resolution at the Security Council and be present during the vote.
Political officials say that the Palestinians are looking for ways to embarrass Israel.
The Israeli UN delegation was unaware that the Palestinians were planning on putting forward this draft.
Netanyahu's office published a strong response to the draft resolution, saying that it will push negotiations farther away.
Israeli Ambassador to the UN Danny Danon said that the Palestinians need to understand that there are no shortcuts and that the only way to progress negotiations is through direct negotiations.
f1f808ba6f1f45285b096101b17fabb9:
The Palestinian U.N. Mission has circulated a proposed Security Council resolution condemning Israeli settlements to Arab nations.
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu condemned the draft, saying Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas “is taking a step that will push negotiations further away” to end the decades-old Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
The Palestinians refused to provide any details of the resolution.
The Security Council resolution on settlements in February 2011 was defeated by a U.S. veto.
Israel captured the West Bank, Gaza Strip and east Jerusalem in the 1967 Mideast War and built settlements there.
The Palestinians claim those areas as parts of a future state.
5c5c330b3d94a7515dcfa8f31c3a55b7:
The Palestinian mission to the United Nations is circulating a Security Council draft resolution condemning Israel’s illegal settlements in the occupied territories.
The draft resolution includes a clause condemning Israeli settler violence against Palestinians.
The Palestinians want the 15-member council to vote on the resolution when Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas visits New York on April 22.
Israel fears US President Barack Obama may no longer wish to veto the resolution calling for end to settlement construction.
The Israeli NGO, Peace Now, says Israel began building 1,800 new settler units in the occupied West Bank in 2015.
The European Union censured the Israeli regime for its plans to expropriate Palestinian lands in the West Bank.
Britain has also slammed Israel’s decision to further expand settlements in the West Bank.
More than half a million Israelis live in over 230 illegal settlements built since the 1967 Israeli occupation of Palestinian territories in the West Bank and East al-Quds (Jerusalem).
Tel Aviv has resumed construction work on a section of its Apartheid Wall separating parts of the West Bank from the bulk of the occupied territory.
The Israeli military has more than tripled the demolitions of Palestinian structures in the occupied West Bank over the past three months.
The demolitions have raised alarm among diplomats and human rights groups over what they regard as the Tel Aviv regime’s continued violation of international law.
Israeli military forces demolished a number of Palestinian structures across the occupied territories on Thursday.
The Israeli forces have destroyed more than 500 Palestinian structures since the beginning of the current year.
0b2d0c023a07da468989ad9ab1ac9303:
A draft proposal for a new UN Security Council resolution seeks “accountability” for Israeli settlement building.
The draft resolution stresses the “violence and terrorism of the settlers.”
Israel’s Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu condemned the draft resolution, saying Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas “is taking a step that will push negotiations further away” to end the decades-old Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
The Palestinians refused to provide any details of the text, but said the Security Council has unanimously agreed that Israeli settlements are illegal and it is their responsibility to act on this assessment and adopt a resolution on settlements.
Israel captured the West Bank, Gaza Strip and East Jerusalem in the 1967 Six Day war and built settlements there.
Israel began building 1,800 new settlement homes in the West Bank in 2015.
The Palestinians claim the West Bank, Gaza and East Jerusalem as parts of a future state, a position that has wide global support.
The United States has nonetheless opposed new settlements, saying they are an impediment to peace between Israel and the Palestinians.
The Israeli newspaper Haaretz reported that the Palestinians want the Security Council to vote when Abbas is in New York on April 22 to attend the high-level ceremony where more than 130 countries are expected to sign the landmark climate agreement reached in Paris in December.
Netanyahu accused Abbas of avoiding direct negotiations, and Israel’s UN Ambassador Danny Danon said the only way to promote negotiations must start with the Palestinians “condemning terrorism and stopping the incitement.”
b456533ae45cfc1c94e7edf9aad5d61b:
A draft resolution by the Palestinian Authority calls for the immediate resumption of peace talks with Israel and a final status agreement within a year, as well as a complete halt to all Israeli settlement activity.
The draft resolution was posted to the UN Report blog on Friday and first reported by Israeli daily Haaretz.
The Palestinians want the Security Council to vote when PA President Mahmoud Abbas is in New York on April 22 for a high-level signing ceremony for the landmark climate agreement reached in Paris in December.
The draft resolution reiterates the Palestinian demand that Israel “immediately and completely cease all settlement activities in the Occupied Palestinian Territories, including East Jerusalem.”
The draft resolution also calls for both parties “to refrain from provocative actions, incitement and inflammatory rhetoric.”
The draft resolution stresses the importance of the Arab Peace Initiative, which proposed a complete end to the Arab-Israeli conflict in return for a complete Israeli withdrawal from land conquered in the 1967 Six Day War.
The international community considers Israeli settlements illegitimate, while Israel says settlements and other core issues such as security should be resolved in peace talks.
Netanyahu condemned the UN draft last Thursday, accusing Abbas of “taking a step that will push negotiations further away.”
The UN Security Council last voted to condemn Israeli settlements in February 2011, but the resolution was defeated by a US veto.
a39c890de8a24a3582dce4972f367dab:
Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas said there is an “urgent” need for a UN resolution condemning Israeli settlements.
The Palestinians are currently discussing a new draft resolution at the UN Security Council on the subject.
The draft resolution defines Israeli settlements as illegal and calls for a one-year timetable to reach a final status agreement.
The resolution was written up in consultation with Security Council members, but will likely be stymied by a US veto.
Abbas criticized what he said was insufficient action from the White House.
Abbas firmly backed a French initiative to hold an international peace conference this summer.
Abbas will begin a two-week tour to Turkey, France, Russia, Germany and New York on Tuesday.
Peace efforts have been at a complete standstill since a US initiative collapsed two years ago.
fc1b5dc0d8d5af1ba94274eee0585eb6:
Unlike in December 2014, Israel has virtually no chance of preventing the latest Palestinian attempt to get Israel condemned at the UN Security Council.
The key to fending off the latest Palestinian attempt lies with US President Barack Obama.
A leaked draft of the proposed resolution expresses “grave concern” over dwindling prospects of a two-state solution and calls on Israel to “immediately and completely cease all settlement activities in the Occupied Palestinian Territories, including East Jerusalem.”
The draft further urges the “intensification and acceleration of international and regional diplomatic efforts and support aimed at achieving, without delay, an end to the Israeli occupation that began in 1967.”
The draft does not explicitly set a 12-month deadline for negotiations on a final peace deal with Israel and an imposed full Israeli withdrawal from the West Bank and East Jerusalem within three years, as a resolution proposed in late December 2014 did.
For a resolution to pass it needs nine votes from the council’s 15 members.
Only a US veto can stop the resolution.
Since 2014, the makeup of the Security Council has changed in the Palestinians’ favor, and there is virtually no chance for Israel to stave off a resolution critical of settlements.
The US thus remains the only wildcard in the upcoming diplomatic showdown at Turtle Bay.
In February 2011, a resolution condemning Israel’s settlements — without establishing deadlines for an Israel withdrawal — got 14 yes votes but stumbled over Washington’s veto.
The US needs regional Arab allies in its fight against the Islamic State group and may not want to antagonize them over the Palestinian question.
Obama might still be bitter over Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s blatant effort to thwart the nuclear deal with Iran by addressing the US Congress and trying to get American Jews to oppose their government.
Failure to block the resolution would give ample ammunition to domestic political opponents trying to portray the Democrats as anti-Israel, and threatens to erode Jewish support for the party ahead of the November presidential elections.
e7e26ea74aa8ef510a156153e5af1c9c:
Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas urges for a UN resolution on Israeli settlements.
The Palestinians are discussing a UN draft resolution condemning Israeli settlements in the occupied West Bank.
Abbas will tour Turkey, France, Russia, Germany and New York.
The United States has repeatedly vetoed resolutions on Israel at the UN Security Council.
Israeli settlements are considered illegal under international law and are seen as major stumbling blocks to peace efforts.
Some 210 Palestinians have lost their lives at the hands of Israeli forces since the beginning of last October.
75,000 Palestinians are still internally displaced in the Gaza Strip less than two years after the Israeli military's 50-day war on the besieged enclave.
23 percent of Gazans are still living in rubble of their destroyed homes.
Nearly half of the displaced families (47 percent) do not have enough food to eat.
Three in four Gazans depend on trucked water because of inadequate clean water supplies from taps.
More than 1,500 children were orphaned in the 2014 war.
551 children lost their lives and another 3,436 sustained injuries in the 2014 war.
Nearly one in six displaced children has been suffering from increased psycho-social distress since the 2014 war.
More than 30 percent of internally displaced women live in tents, makeshift shelters, destroyed houses and the open air.
The UN body expressed concern over Israeli regime's restrictions on the import of cement into the blockaded Palestinian enclave.
More than 2,200 Palestinians were killed in the 2014 war.
Gaza has been blockaded since 2007, a situation that has caused a decline in the standard of living, unprecedented levels of unemployment, and unrelenting poverty.
e6b97cbe11efc649a08895cb9eb04237:
The Palestinian issue is experiencing paralysis due to international, regional, local and personal reasons.
The US has basically frozen the peace process led by Secretary of State John Kerry.
America’s abandonment of the peace process has been intensified by the run-up to the presidential election.
Russia is challenging the Obama administration, which does not dare to engage it on the field of battle.
A number of other international forces have also emerged, with different perspectives and influences.
The situation in Palestine has been influenced by events which are redrawing the maps across the Middle East.
The most dangerous aspect for the Palestinians is the pressure from the Egyptian government and its allies.
The closures and restrictions at the Egyptian-controlled Rafah border crossing are worse than those at the Erez crossing into Israel.
The failure of the peace process and security coordination with the occupation authorities has been a thorn in the side of the Palestinian people.
The failure of the reconciliation negotiations that were activated with Hamas a month ago has caused a local deadlock.
The current phase requires a rejection of the impasse and for the main forces to take the lead in Palestinian affairs.
Fatah needs to reunite and steer clear of internal factionalism centred on the succession to Abbas.
Unity must lead to serious and strategic national reconciliation that is not linked to any regional or international developments and rises above the internal conflicts and balance of power.
All of the Palestinian factions must participate in the reconciliation process.
57fe274d3501bfb71cf96685de84fff7:
UNESCO's Executive Board adopted a resolution that ignored Jewish ties to the Temple Mount and the Western Wall area in Jerusalem's Old City.
The resolution condemned Israeli actions in east Jerusalem, the West Bank and Gaza, with a focus on the Temple Mount and the Western Wall Plaza.
The resolution referred to the Temple Mount area solely as the Al-Aksa Mosque/Al-Haram Al Sharif, except for two references to the Western Wall Plaza in parenthesis.
The resolution called for Israel to restore the situation on the Temple Mount to what it had been prior to September 2000, when the Second Intifada broke out.
The resolution condemned Israeli plans to build a prayer space for Women of the Wall by Robinson's Arch.
The resolution charged that Israel had planned "Jewish fake graves" in other Muslim cemeteries located on Wakf property east and south of the Al-Aksa mosque.
The resolution passed with 33 votes in favor, six against and 17 abstentions.
The United States, Germany, the United Kingdom, Estonia, Lithuania and the Netherlands opposed the resolution.
France, Spain, Slovenia, Sweden, Russia and Slovenia supported the resolution.
618aa0a71177f93a0a4be3fd558bb312:
The Palestinian Authority has circulated a draft Security Council resolution to UN diplomats, demanding that Israel cease all settlement activities in the Occupied Palestinian territories, including East Jerusalem.
The draft resolution blames specifically only Israeli settlers for "acts of terror, violence, destruction, harassment and provocation," while not mentioning the constant violence committed by Palestinians against Israeli civilians.
The draft resolution reportedly has the support of enough members of the Security Council to be adopted, absent a veto by the United States.
The Obama administration may decide to abstain, if not actually vote yes in concert with the prevailing sentiment among other Security Council members.
The Obama administration may back another course, reportedly being developed by France, which favors putting the Security Council on record as endorsing parameters of a two-state solution along the lines of what the Palestinians have been seeking with the support of the Arab states.
Alternatively, Obama may decide that the United States should sponsor its own resolution, laying out Obama’s proposal for a two state solution that is largely the same as the Palestinian approach, freezing all settlements and pushing Israel virtually all the way back to the insecure pre-1967 lines.
The Palestinian leadership’s true intentions are to establish the pre-1967 lines, with minor adjustments, as the new Palestinian state’s permanent border with Israel, but Israel would not be left alone to remain a Jewish state even then.
Hamas remains committed to ridding Israel of all Jews – by genocide, if that becomes the most expedient method.
394 members of the 435-member House of Representatives wrote President Obama a letter last week urging Obama to direct a veto of any such “one-sided United Nations Security Council resolutions.”
16afdb1d3d02ec7ff46b23c3e3f5c0d5:
Israeli Ambassador Danny Danon demanded that the Palestinian representative condemn acts of terrorism during a UN Security Council debate.
Palestinian Ambassador Riyad Mansour responded by accusing Israel of killing Palestinian children.
The council debate took place as the Palestinians pushed for a UN resolution demanding that Israel halt the construction of settlements in the Palestinian territories.
UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon said in an address that Israeli demolitions of Palestinian buildings in the West Bank were continuing at "an alarming rate."
The latest surge of violence over the past six months has killed some 30 Israelis and 200 Palestinians.
The United Nations supports a two-state solution in the Middle East, with Israel and Palestine both recognized countries.
The Middle East quartet is working on a report about how to restart peace efforts.
France is pushing for an international conference to jumpstart negotiations.
dec939fee9c3f6e3cf9b46e964a225bb:
Israeli Ambassador Danny Danon and Palestinian envoy Riyad Mansour engaged in a rare shouting match in the UN Security Council on Monday.
Danon demanded Mansour to condemn Palestinians who commit terror attacks against Israelis, while Mansour retorted by asking Danon to condemn the killing of all innocent civilians including Palestinian civilians.
Danon accused the Palestinians of teaching "hatred" in schools, naming streets after "terrorists," and paying the families of terrorists.
Mansour denied Danon's accusations and retorted by saying "Shame on you for killing thousands of Palestinian children."
Mansour said the Palestinians are moving ahead on a Security Council resolution that would address Israeli settlements in the West Bank and aim at de-escalating the volatile situation.
Danon said when the Palestinians end their "campaign of hate and violence," and teach respect for all people in their schools, "they will find a partner ready to work with them for the promise of peace."
95f6baf8a51f7513ba719a50bfbfbc28:
United Nations Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon warned that a two-state solution in the Middle East seems more distant than it has for many decades.
Over six months of violence, triggered by individual terrorist attacks by Palestinians, have gripped Israel and the Occupied Palestinian Territory, resulting in the deaths of more than two dozen Israelis and two hundred Palestinians.
Israel continues to demolish Palestinian structures in the West Bank at an alarming rate, with more than 700 people displaced in the first three months of 2016.
Israel's strategic settlement enterprise continues to expand on land intended for a future Palestinian state.
The Palestinian Government has laid out an ambitious $3.8 billion agenda for stabilizing Gaza, repairing damage from the 2014 conflict, and getting recovery underway.
Lebanon's model of pluralism and coexistence must be preserved from regional tensions.
The Lebanese Armed Forces need sustained international support.
Lebanon and Israel must work to consolidate stability along the Blue Line and advance the implementation of resolution 1701.
Eight countries and the European Union pledged $1 billion for a concessional loan facility, $141 million in grants, and $500 million for a guarantee facility to support countries disproportionately impacted by the conflict in Syria.
f52436dd5fd959010ce2b7a3c84f5a20:
The Palestinian National Authority (PNA) plans to adopt the Jordanian or US currencies instead of the Israeli shekel in Palestinian commerce and daily transactions.
The Palestinian Monetary Authority and Ministry of Finance and Economy are quietly considering and studying abandoning the Israeli shekel in the Palestinian territories.
The Palestinians could use the US dollar or the Jordanian dinar in their commerce and transactions, but the Palestinians with the passage of time mainly used the Israeli shekel.
The Israelis insist on using only the shekel in their commerce with the Palestinians and categorically refuse to do any business with the use of the US currency.
Dr Nasr Abdul Kareem, an expert economist in the West Bank, supports abandoning the Israeli shekel from the daily life of Palestinians.
Adopting a new currency in Palestine should be carefully considered and implemented where the Palestinian economy must be restructured giving the residents the chance to settle their shekel transactions.
The Israeli reaction to the suspension of the shekel and adoption of another currency must also be carefully reviewed and evaluated in advance.
Abandoning the Israeli shekel and adopting another currency will and should take a long time — three to four years — and should be implemented gradually.
Politically, abandoning the shekel is a fundamental move in the process of cutting relations with Israel.
98aa18c5080908053aa955cf8b2f007e:
Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas criticized Israel for destroying the climate and environment in Palestine during the signing ceremony of the Paris climate accord.
Israeli Ambassador Danny Danon responded by accusing Abbas of spreading hatred and exploiting the international stage to mislead the international community.
Danon and Palestinian envoy Riyad Mansour yelled "shame on you" at each other during a regular U.N. Security Council meeting on the situation in the Middle East earlier this week.
Palestine's accession to the Paris climate accord could lead to complications for the United States, which has a law barring U.S. funding for "any organization or group that does not have the internationally recognized attributes of statehood."
21 Republican Senators sent a letter to Secretary of State John Kerry saying that Palestine's participation in the U.N. climate change secretariat and the Paris agreement would prohibit the United States from paying money into a global climate fund.
4a4f5d3dbd42f8fb521d84ef5127eac3:
Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas criticized Israel for destroying the climate and environment in Palestine during the signing ceremony for the Paris climate accord.
Israeli Ambassador Danny Danon responded by accusing Abbas of spreading hatred and exploiting the international stage to mislead the international community.
Abbas' presence at the signing ceremony had symbolic importance as it was the first time a Palestinian president sat in the General Assembly hall as a state party to a treaty at a signing ceremony.
Palestine's accession to the treaty could lead to complications for the United States, which has a law barring U.S. funding for organizations without internationally recognized attributes of statehood.
21 Republican Senators sent a letter to Secretary of State John Kerry saying that Palestine's participation in the U.N. climate change secretariat and the Paris agreement would prohibit the United States from paying money into a global climate fund.
8508e3d42bbc1ab4e3e685db892e3955:
A UNESCO resolution on Jerusalem describes and puts the Western Wall Plaza in quotation marks.
The resolution was adopted by the United Nations cultural agency's 58-nation executive board last week.
The resolution decries the renovation of and the alleged desecration of holy sites.
The Western Wall is in East Jerusalem's historic Old City, which was occupied by Israel along with the rest of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip during the 1967 Middle East war.
Israel's parliament, the Knesset, passed the Jerusalem Law in 1980, which declared the city "complete and united".
The Israeli government described the resolution, which was voted for by 33 countries, as "hideous" and penned letters to all countries that signed the resolution, which included France, Russia and China.
The UNESCO resolution has sparked anger in Israel.
Dore Gold, director general of the country's foreign ministry, said in a statement on Thursday that the resolution "has no legal standing".
72c8dc09dc61487494b164611521a1b3:
Palestinian envoy Riyad Mansour said the renewed Palestinian drive to persuade the U.N. Security Council to condemn Israeli settlements is aimed at removing the biggest obstacle to peace and boosting French efforts to broker an agreement.
The draft resolution about Israeli settlements in east Jerusalem and the West Bank was received by Arab delegations.
The United States vetoed a similar resolution about Israel’s settlements five years ago because of fears it would undermine peace talks.
The United States considers Israeli settlements on land the Palestinians want for a future state to be illegitimate.
Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas will be in New York next week to sign the Paris climate agreement and is expected to meet with French President Francois Hollande to discuss the Palestinian draft resolution.
Israel’s Ambassador to the United Nations Danny Danon said the Palestinians must understand that there are no shortcuts and the only way to promote negotiations is by condemning terrorism and stopping the incitement.
39cf64c5764d27bb60adc26e1532c94f:
The West’s refusal to challenge the growing corruption and autocratic rule of Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas could have a devastating effect on the long-term prospects for a viable Palestinian state.
Abbas has tested the limits of Western leniency since the end of the American-sponsored talks two years ago, which Abbas himself torpedoed.
Abbas is becoming increasingly dictatorial, establishing a new constitutional court whose members are all picked by Abbas and issuing a warrant for the arrest of a Palestinian legislator who accused an Abbas ally of corruption.
The PA set up roadblocks to prevent teachers from marching on Ramallah, arrested the leaders of the teachers’ union, and threatened legal action unless they returned to work when teachers launched an unprecedented strike over the PA’s broken promises to raise their wages.
In 2015, 60 percent of the nearly 200 violations of press freedom in Palestinian territories occurred in the PA-governed West Bank, with only 40 percent occurring in Hamas-ruled Gaza.
Abbas is using the final year of President Barack Obama’s term in office as an opportunity for the “consolidation of power at home” and to “further isolate Israel.”
Abbas’s increasingly tyrannical government in the West Bank does not only handicap political expression—it also sets back the very legitimacy of the Palestinian national project.
Other experts have raised concerns about the PA’s corruption and its effect on the viability of a future Palestinian state.
American and European support for the Palestinian Authority now totals hundreds of billions of dollars—possibly trillions if non-governmental activities are included.
Donors should insist on fiscal and legal reforms, as well as the establishment of robust and independent institutions—judiciary and education included.
d965e2f84ac6fae1895edc74e035d153:
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu invited a senior UN official to a lecture on Jewish history.
The invitation was in response to a UN resolution condemning Israeli “aggression” against Muslims at Jerusalem’s Al-Aqsa Mosque compound.
The UN’s special coordinator for the Middle East peace process, Nickolay Mladenov, declined the invitation, saying that UN staff in Jerusalem are well-educated on the region's history.
adc6ea30a8edf8e817b9086066f80485:
Venezuelan Ambassador to the UN Rafael Ramirez accused Israel of implementing a "final solution" against the Palestinians in the UN Security Council.
Israeli Ambassador to the UN Danny Danon condemned the statement, and Ramirez apologized to "the Jewish people, if they were offended by my statement."
Yesh Din organization presented statistics pertaining to law enforcement as it relates to crimes of an ideological nature carried out by Israeli citizens against Palestinians to the UN Security Council.
Yesh Din representative Michael Sfard presented the organization's assertion that the violence carried out against Palestinians is designed to drive them off of their land.
Israeli Ambassador Danon responded harshly to Ramirez's statements, calling them "blunt anti-Semitic statements."
The US, Britain, and France decisively condemned the Venezuelan ambassador's statements.
ab24cfa1d014557e52f5b8ec600bd20a:
Venezuela’s ambassador to the United Nations, Rafael Ramirez, compared Israel to the Nazi regime and asked if Israel planned to “wage a final solution” against the Palestinians.
Israel’s ambassador to the United Nations, Danny Danon, accused Ramirez of “clear anti-Semitism.”
Ramirez’s comments came a day after Israel marked Holocaust Remembrance Day.
The Palestinian Authority’s UN envoy, Riyad Mansour, compared the recent spate of Palestinian attacks on Israelis to the action by Jewish resistance fighters during the Holocaust.
The US, United Kingdom and France condemned Ramirez’s comments.
Ramirez apologized to the “Jewish people if they were offended by the remarks.”
ef90229562be82ba5691f4d9eec99632:
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu offered to teach history to UN personnel in Israel.
The offer was rejected by the United Nations Special Coordinator for the Middle East Peace Process, Nickolay Mladenov.
Netanyahu's offer came in response to recent UNESCO resolutions referring to Israel as an “occupying power” and claiming several sites holy to Judaism as Muslim sites.
The resolutions refer to the Temple Mount as Al-Haram al-Sharif and Al-Aqsa Mosque, and to Al-Buraq Plaza with ‘Western Wall’ in parentheses.
The resolution was approved by 33 states, including France, Russia, Spain and Sweden.
Seventeen countries abstained while six voted against including the United States, Estonia, Germany, Lithuania, the Netherlands and the United Kingdom.
fca72b70b493da994fdafcb043b546a5:
French Interior Minister Bernard Cazeneuve criticized France's vote at UNESCO for a resolution that ignored Jewish historical ties to Jerusalem and its holy sites.
Cazeneuve said he does not support the text that France voted to approve and that it should not have been adopted.
The resolution refers to the Temple Mount area solely as the Al-Aqsa Mosque/Al-Haram Al Sharif, except for two references to the Western Wall Plaza that were put in parentheses.
French Chief Rabbi Haim Korsia expressed his strong disapproval of the French vote and urged the UNESCO executive council to reconsider their position.
Cazeneuve said his position on the matter is the same as Haim Korsia's.
8b1389eb88615e91736abf1e8f33257a:
Palestinian street attacks against Israelis have waned in the past half year, according to Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.
Since October, Palestinians have killed 28 Israelis and two U.S. citizens in knife, car-ramming and gun assaults.
Israeli forces killed at least 190 Palestinians during the wave of violence, 129 of whom Israel says were assailants.
Netanyahu attributed the decline in attacks to Israeli security forces' "very firm action against incitement" and their foiling of assaults.
Hamas condemned the arrest of three West Bank Palestinians by Abbas's forces on suspicion of planning to attack Israel as "very grave."
Palestinian authorities in the West Bank played down the case, saying the three were tracked down at the request of their families after their went missing.
The last instance of a Palestinian carrying out a fatal attack in Israel occurred on March 9, when an American tourist was stabbed to death in Tel Aviv.
30413144b84ffc0cea2dcd08aa65ea62:
Prime Minister Binyamin Netanyahu announced a decline in terror attacks after months of escalation.
The decline in terror attacks is attributed to the government's strong, responsible and methodical policy.
The IDF, ISA and Israel Police are commended for their alertness and combined offensive and defensive effort.
Terrorism tends to have a snowball effect, with successful attacks inspiring others to follow suit.
Reducing the success rate of terrorism reduces the number of those joining.
The government will discuss a multi-year plan for strengthening the security of Jerusalem, improving law enforcement and boosting personal security in the Arab sector.
The plan includes building new police stations, recruiting 2,600 officers and strengthening police operational capabilities.
The goal is to achieve equality in law enforcement and reduce gaps in society at large and in Israeli Arab society.
410d7d996adf084631f7770d43d21054:
Maj.-Gen. (res.) Amos Gilad warned that Mohammed Deif, the head of Hamas's military wing, "doesn't care about the political bureau's policies, and does whatever he wants."
Deif has survived several Israeli assassination attempts, the latest of which was during Operation Protective Edge in the summer of 2014.
Gilad said that Israel's deterrence works on both the military and political wings of Hamas.
Hamas has been unsuccessful in its efforts to further escalate the violence between Israel and the Palestinians.
Gilad noted that Hamas's central ideology is that there is no place for agreements with Israel.
Gilad warned that the electricity Israel provides the Gaza Strip "is being used for the production of rockets that are later aimed at Israel."
Despite this, Gilad said, Israel will continue aiding the Palestinians with a series of economic measures that share a common policy - not to allow Gaza to collapse.
abc8f5d52d62b1186e92ff7127c6769a:
Hamas is amassing fighters and materiel at a "surprisingly" quick pace in the Gaza Strip.
Hamas has replenished some of its ranks, principally in its special forces and commando naval units, and now has some 5,000 fighters in its special forces.
Hamas has also filled out its middle and upper ranks, with 25 battalion and brigade commanders.
Hamas has focused on replacing its short-range rocket and mortar programs, with some new rockets having warheads that contain hundreds of pounds of explosive material.
Hamas has also developed some medium- and long-range rockets.
Hamas has made strides in the production of drones and other advanced technologies, under the direction of Iran.
Hamas is not yet mass producing mortars because of its difficulties in obtaining raw materials.
Hamas fears a surprise attack from Israel and has worked to prevent instigators from giving Israel any reason to carry out operations in the Strip.
Hamas has created a defensive force that preserves the ceasefire and prevents terror attacks against Israel.
The IDF will not be dragged into conflict with Hamas, but will initiate any conflict with the terrorist group.
The IDF has drawn up an extensive battle plan for its troops, including "details and defining characteristics" of the enemy battalions.
The IDF plan rests on the defense of the area surrounding the Gaza Strip while moving the areas where troops gather away from the threat of mortars.
The IDF has an interest in the Egyptian army defeating the Islamic State and not losing its control over the northern Sinai.
Some 1,000 IS fighters are currently in the Sinai peninsula, and they are outfitted with some advanced anti-aircraft weaponry and assistance from Hamas.
a5e56464469a02c257218c9b09d3ceb6:
Hamas has been working to restore its strength since the 2014 Operation Protective Edge, but has yet to fully replenish its rocket arsenal due to supply shortages and internal tensions.
Hamas is prioritizing military buildup and has established a border-protecting unit to enforce the ceasefire and prevent attacks against Israel.
Hamas's military leadership has become more dominant, challenging the political leadership and executing a battalion commander without approval.
Hamas is investing in training its elite Nukhba force, naval commando unit, and developing drones with Iranian support.
Hamas is developing mortar shells and short-range rockets with larger payloads, focusing on weapons that were effective during Operation Protective Edge.
The IDF has approved an operative plan for fighting in Gaza, aiming to defeat Hamas's military wing and set back its capabilities for years.
The plan emphasizes offensive action, aerial attacks, and strong protection of border communities.
The IDF has prepared battalion commanders with detailed knowledge of Hamas battalions and evacuation plans for communities near the Gaza border.
The IDF currently sees no alternative ruler for Gaza as Hamas retains public support, and assesses that there will be no escalation of hostilities in the near future.
e6b12b48e32dcdbec30349f25e87a50c:
Israel carried out its largest civilian drill near the Gaza Strip border since 2014’s war between Israel and Hamas.
The drill simulated a Hamas incursion into Israeli territory, including an attack on an Israeli kibbutz near the border and the taking of hostages by terrorists.
The IDF has in recent days completed preparations for any outbreak of conflict.
The IDF has boosted its deployment adjacent to the Gaza border in preparation for such an eventuality.
Palestinian media reported that IDF bulldozers entered the Gaza Strip and carried out work near the border fence.
A senior IDF officer said that Hamas is amassing fighters and materiel at a “surprisingly” quick pace in Gaza but that the terror group does not appear to be prepared for renewed direct conflict with Israel in the near future.
Amos Gilad, director of the ministry’s Political-Military Affairs Bureau, said that there is no expectation of an increase in violence with Hamas.
281777fe55e5d0ebe0d81034d73ef975:
Likud member of Knesset Tzachi Hanegbi said Hamas is gaining strength despite being deterred by the 2014 conflict with Israel.
The IDF is preparing for all possibilities, including grave ones, regarding possible new conflict with Hamas.
Israel carried out its largest civilian drill near the Gaza Strip border since 2014.
The IDF has boosted its deployment adjacent to the Gaza border in preparation for any outbreak of conflict.
Hamas is amassing fighters and materiel at a “surprisingly” quick pace in Gaza but does not appear to be prepared for renewed direct conflict with Israel in the near future.
The IDF believes Hamas does not want a new war now.
12d17d5586938650b2569606e5fd0c61:
Hamas is enhancing its arsenal and training its operatives, especially from its elite “Nukhbah” terror unit.
Hamas’s special forces currently include some 20,000 operatives.
Hamas is developing its drone and naval capabilities, including terrorist divers.
Hamas is actively pursuing improved rocket-launching capabilities.
Hamas is focusing on developing its short-range projectile fire apparatus, which proved more effective during the summer 2014 war with Israel.
Hamas is trying to increase the amount of explosives its arsenal of short-range projectiles can carry.
Hamas is developing mid-range rockets that could “escape” the Iron Dome.
Hamas is concerned that Israel is planning an operation in Gaza.
Hamas saw the [months-long terror wave] in Judea and Samaria as a strategic opportunity it hoped to seize.
Hamas is disappointed by the fact the situation in Judea and Samaria has stabilized.
28c0732094862bcaa58b8312f20d155a:
Israeli Education Minister Naftali Bennett has applauded the IDF's success in locating and destroying a massive terrorist attack tunnel from Gaza into Israel.
Hamas's top priority is to carry out a multi-pronged, mass-casualty infiltration attack from Gaza into southern Israeli communities.
Bennett has been credited for pushing the government to initiate an IDF operation during 2014's Operation Protective Edge.
Bennett has since clashed with Ya'alon and Prime Minister Netanyahu on security issues, criticizing them for not taking a hard enough stance.
Hamas has turned tunnel construction into a "national priority," and is investing massively in plans to launch an even greater attack.
Hamas's objective is to surprise Israel with a multi-front infiltration attack, including killings and kidnappings.
Israel needs to prevent such a scenario recurring "at any price, and not to rely on Hamas being 'deterred'."
53b4c6bdbce48f9599826787528b082b:
Hamas has been tunneling under the border with Israel again.
Israel has confirmed that Hamas has been tunneling under the border.
Hamas has been improving its rocket capabilities.
Hamas may believe it has an urgent incentive to attack Israel again in the near future.
Hamas has been gaining strength at a "surprising" pace.
Hamas has been utilizing some 1,000 tunnelers, working round-the-clock six days a week.
Israel has been making gains in its battle against Hamas's tunnels.
Hamas may feel that now is the time to attack Israel.
a24a78c9d1789070c28e76ea7b1bd20a:
Residents of Gaza border towns, journalists and political opponents accused Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s Likud government of failing to address the threat of Hamas-dug attack tunnels from the Strip.
IDF Southern Command head Maj. Gen. Eyal Zamir attempted to reassure the crowd that the army had things under control, stating that "the period since Operation Protective Edge has been the most quiet period in a decade."
Zamir added that "we have detailed plans on how to respond to any Hamas aggression, and are operating constantly along the border."
The heads of opposition parties — the Zionist Union’s Isaac Herzog, Yesh Atid’s Yair Lapid, Yisrael Beytenu’s Avigdor Liberman and Meretz’s Zehava Galon — spoke at the conference, offering their parties’ answers to the threat of attack tunnels.
Likud could only muster Miki Zohar, a freshman MK who is 22nd on the party’s list and is best known for proposing stricter legislation against businesses that remain open on Shabbat.
Zohar’s speech was interrupted multiple times, first by audience members who demanded the government do more to protect them from Hamas, and then by Cushmaro himself, who derided the MK’s speech as light on content.
Col. (res.) Yossi Langotzky, who previously served as adviser to the IDF chief of staff on the threat of tunnels, called Zohar “an idiot” for his comments on tunnel detection technology.
Liberman advocated a lessening of some of the restrictions on imports and exports for the coastal enclave, emphasizing the importance of easing the economic crisis in Gaza, which he claimed has been fueling the conflict.
Galon advocated a dramatic change in policy, one that puts more emphasis on the need for negotiations in place of violent conflict to resolve the issues coming from Gaza.
Herzog blasted the government and security cabinet as being short on action and long on word, as part of his recent bid to appear tough on terror.
885b99a0ce6b8dcb46c98d5eb877c128:
Hamas deployed forces along the Egypt-Gaza border to counter Cairo's concerns that Hamas is aiding Islamic State extremists in Egypt's Sinai Peninsula.
Egypt accuses Hamas of providing a safe haven for the IS affiliate in Sinai through a network of smuggling tunnels.
Hamas denies the charge.
The deployment is part of an agreement reached with Egyptian officials last month.
Hamas has halted tunnel construction in return for opening the Rafah border crossing, Gaza's main gateway to the outside world.
Armed Hamas men took up positions along the 13-kilometer (8-mile) border, with fighters in pick-up trucks patrolling back and forth.
Relations between Hamas and Egypt soured after the 2013 military ouster of Islamist President Mohammed Morsi.
Egypt has been battling IS militants and in 2014 launched a fierce campaign on the underground tunnels with Gaza, destroying many of them.
Egypt has also kept the Rafah crossing largely sealed.
Hamas hopes that the deal will lead to the crossing's reopening.
c2e86025a29e7a00b40b484850839a62:
Gaza’s Interior Ministry and National Security redeployed forces along the frontier with Egypt to increase control over the border area.
Hamas had begun deploying additional forces on the Gaza border to ease Cairo's concerns about security.
The deployment coincided with a planned tour of the southern Gaza Strip border area by leaders of the Interior Ministry and of “Islamist and national” forces.
Egypt and Gaza’s Hamas rulers have had tensions for several years, as Cairo has accused Hamas of being involved in the terrorist attacks in the Sinai.
Egypt accused Hamas of involvement, along with the outlawed Muslim Brotherhood, in last year's killing of the country's top prosecutor, Hisham Barakat, an allegation which Hamas denied.
Egypt began creating a wide buffer zone along the Gaza border in late 2014 to destroy the hundreds of smuggling tunnels Cairo says are used by Palestinian Arabs to deliver weapons to jihadists in the Sinai Peninsula.
Egypt said Hamas assisted Sinai Province in two deadly attacks in El-Arish in 2014.
Egypt has also destroyed and flooded hundreds of tunnels as part of the ongoing security campaign in the northern Sinai Peninsula.
584adcf6b76ceabd5aafe822da42a901:
Hamas has deployed forces along the Egyptian-Gaza border to address Cairo’s concerns that Hamas is aiding terrorists from the Islamic State group in Egypt’s lawless Sinai Peninsula.
Hamas denies the accusations that it is providing a safe haven for IS’s Sinai affiliate through a network of smuggling tunnels.
Hamas says the deployment is part of an agreement reached with Egyptian officials last month.
Analysts describe the deployment as a unilateral step by Hamas to send assurances to Cairo.
Relations between Hamas and Egypt soured after the 2013 military ouster of Islamist president Mohammed Morsi.
ed4458bb29a428ab3d3a144948e1c2e9:
Hamas has set up dozens of new border posts and military checkpoints along the Gaza Strip's border with Egypt to improve relations with Cairo.
Hamas has deployed an additional 600 soldiers along its 13-kilometer (eight-mile) southern border to bolster security.
Hamas has for the first time established three checkpoints within a few hundred meters of Israeli lookout towers.
Hamas official Tawfiq Abu Naim told troops that Egypt’s security was Hamas’s security.
Hamas has agreed to control the border area between Gaza and Egypt to stop infiltration of Palestinians and weapons from Gaza to Egypt and Salafists from Sinai into the Gaza Strip.
In exchange, Egypt will consider easing border restrictions at the Rafah border crossing with Gaza.
Hamas’s ultimate goal is to improve the relationship with the Egyptians to the point where they open the Rafah crossing as it was when Morsi was in power.
90fc0cdb5a6f577c9e08c27da592f3d3:
Hamas has set up dozens of new border posts and military checkpoints along the Gaza Strip's border with Egypt to improve relations with Cairo.
Hamas has deployed an additional 600 soldiers along its 13-kilometre southern border with Egypt.
Hamas has established three checkpoints within a few hundred metres of Israeli lookout towers.
Hamas official Tawfiq Abu Naim said that Egypt's security was Hamas's security.
Khaled al-Batsh, a leader in the Islamic Jihad movement in the Palestinian territory, said his group was also committed to Egypt's security.
Hamas and Egypt have agreed to look to the future and try to forget about the past.
Hamas was asked by the Egyptians to control the border area between Gaza and Egypt to stop infiltration of Palestinians and weapons from Gaza to Egypt and Salafists from Sinai into the Gaza Strip.
Hamas's ultimate goal is to improve the relationship with the Egyptians to the point where they open the Rafah crossing as it was when Morsi was in power.
297196bcf41ac8b61061beaa3919a31c:
Israel and Hamas have been escalating their war of words, which observers on both sides fear could turn into violence.
Gaza has yet to recover from the destruction of the last war with Israel in the summer of 2014, when more than 178,000 houses were destroyed or damaged.
An anonymous senior Israeli officer made an unprecedented statement about Israel Defense Forces (IDF) plans for the next potential military confrontation with Hamas in Gaza.
The Israeli plan for a potential war against Hamas in Gaza calls for each Israeli battalion to kill as many Hamas members as possible and thwart the movement’s moves and goals.
The IDF has developed a strong defense and attack system capable of protecting the Gaza envelope and minimizing the threat of mortar shells, while the Israeli air force would launch an extraordinary and efficient offensive.
Abu Mujahid, a spokesman for the Popular Resistance Committees, said the resistance in Gaza is preparing itself for the worst in its upcoming confrontation with the Israeli army.
Israel announced April 18 that it had discovered a new tunnel east of Rafah in the southern Gaza Strip, noting that the tunnel is 2 kilometers (1.24 miles) long, 30 meters (almost 100 feet) deep and extends inside Israel.
Izz ad-Din al-Qassam Brigades, Hamas' military wing, issued a statement saying Israel’s supposed "discovery" was designed to distract the public's attention away from criticism targeting Israeli leaders for stalling the process of eliminating the Gaza tunnels.
Hamas noted that it has more in store for Israel than a tunnel.
Hamas revealed for the first time its “R 160” missile, which has a range of 160 kilometers (100 miles), meaning it could reach Haifa.
Yousef Rizqa, former Hamas minister of information and a political adviser to Ismail Haniyeh, said Israel’s announcement of discovering the tunnel aims at reassuring the Israeli population that the government is making great efforts to maintain the security of the settlers, confront Hamas and gain international support for Israel.
The more Israel increases its calls to seek out support, the more the expectations for a future war against Gaza increase.
The Israeli army launched large-scale military maneuvers in the Golan Heights and the Jordan Valley that included field forces and aircraft.
The Israeli army had its largest military training since the 2014 war in Gaza, with the participation of thousands of soldiers, near the Gaza border to simulate the incursion of Hamas inside Israeli settlements and the detention of Israeli hostages.
The Ministry of Interior and National Security in Gaza ended the fifth maneuver of its security services, which it had started in Gaza during recent weeks.
Retired Palestinian Maj. Gen. Wassef Erekat said decision-makers within the resistance leadership in Gaza must be alert of the possibility of Israel launching a [surprise] attack.
Israeli Housing Minister Yoav Galant called April 18 for the Israeli army to prepare for a wide-scale confrontation with Hamas in Gaza by the beginning of summer.
Hamas’ and Israel’s declaration of their unwillingness to go into a military confrontation anytime soon might face three factors that may eventually lead to an outbreak of this confrontation.
The Israeli army is preoccupied with the growing unrest in the West Bank that began in October.
Israelis seem to doubt how much the IDF could actually achieve in Gaza — in terms of completely eliminating the Palestinian factions’ missiles and toppling Hamas — except for killing and wounding thousands of Palestinians.
5f7f54f69efc44f052a2a0cd32318b47:
Israel, Egypt and Hamas are cooperating to keep ISIS under control in Sinai.
Israel has tightened its security along the Egyptian border, building a new barrier to keep out militants.
Wilayat Sinai has grown bolder since taking responsibility for downing a Russian charter plane in October, killing all 244 people on board.
Egypt claims it is winning the war against ISIS in Sinai, but its allies fear the claim is suspect.
Multinational peacekeeping forces could become a target for ISIS.
Hamas has deployed over 300 fighters along its border with Sinai to keep ISIS militants out.
b10b1c66f951ff72f6f171c17929bd1e:
Israeli Army Coordinator of Government Activities in the Occupied Territories, Major Maj. -Gen. Yoav ‘Poli’ Mordechai, said the Israeli army will continue its activities in border areas in the Gaza Strip.
Mordechai stated the army intends to continue its operations “against Hamas,” adding that the Hamas movement is “digging tunnels in areas that are under full Israeli control.”
The Israeli army will act against the tunnels in the “Buffer Zone,” across the border fence.
Hamas member of the Political Bureau, Mousa Abu Marzook, thanked the Qatari ambassador in Gaza for “his role in repelling the latest Israeli escalation against Rafah and Sheja’eyya.”
The Israeli army bombarded several areas in the besieged Gaza Strip, causing serious property damage, in addition to wounding an elderly man and three children.
The Israeli army invaded, and bulldozed, Palestinian lands, after advancing approximately 150 meters, northeast of Rafah, in the southern part of the Gaza Strip.
44a1eca1447103d7c08b7b14fc2b76d6:
Israel’s security Cabinet gathered Thursday evening for an emergency meeting on the escalation at the Gaza border.
Israel Air Force planes attacked four Hamas military posts in the southern Gaza Strip in retaliation for mortar attacks from Gaza.
A Palestinian woman in her 50s, identified as Jana Aytah al-Amur, was killed near Khan Yunis in one of the strikes.
Another Palestinian woman, 21, was injured in a strike near Rafah.
The IDF arrested a Hamas operative attempting to infiltrate into Israel from Gaza.
The Hamas operative was deeply involved in the planning of the terror group’s tunnel network from the strip into southern Israel.
The Hamas operative admitted to planning to attack soldiers and Israeli civilians after crossing into Israel.
The Hamas operative conveyed detailed information regarding tunnel trajectory in the northern Gaza Strip, Hamas’ construction methods, and how Hamas utilized private homes and public institutions to hide the tunnels.
2cb19fdecf23867d3fcc8aabe73a9a76:
Israel raised the state of alarm along its border with the Gaza Strip on Wednesday.
Israeli newspaper Maariv reported that the Israeli army told settlers living near the Gaza border to stay at home.
The Israeli army launched artillery attacks on the Gaza Strip.
The Israeli air force carried out five F16 airstrikes on several places in Gaza at dawn yesterday, wounding four people, including three children.
The Israeli army claimed that the artillery shelling came in response to Palestinian mortar attacks against its staff carrying out engineering works along the Gaza border.
ef27b79edbb3edea40c50ad42bd2b334:
Hamas's military wing has realized that the IDF has developed a method to locate their attack tunnels.
The IDF has already discovered at least two tunnels.
Hamas is facing a dilemma of whether to act immediately via their tunnels before they lose their main strategic asset or to refrain from operations and come to terms with the fact that Israel will uncover at least some of the tunnels.
Hamas is not ready for another round of fighting with Israel on the scale of Operation Protective Edge.
The population of Gaza is unable to endure the pain and hardship which will be the result of any major military operation in Gaza.
Hamas fears a major confrontation with Israel at the present time, especially because it's likely that Hamas would lose its political power due to a popular uprising against it.
Hamas has chosen the middle path of firing "deterrence fire" to slow down IDF operations and send a message to Israel that if they keep looking for their tunnels, a war will break out.
The IDF has not been deterred by Hamas's mortars and has increased operations, strengthened forces, and heightened detection efforts.
There are behind-the-scenes talks going on between the Hamas political and military leadership.
The political leadership is putting pressure on the military leadership not to escalate violence, while the military wing is still considering whether to attack the IDF Engineering Corps to mitigate the discovery of additional tunnels.
The political wing is worried about the plight of the civilian population and is trying to convince the military wing to avoid an escalation.
The military and political wings of Hamas, together with the State of Israel and the IDF, have no interest in an escalation, but Hamas's military wing is still entangled in the dilemma of whether to risk losing its attack tunnels or to take the route of the biblical Samson and destroy itself together with the Israelis.
05106cf8c115d4deb76a42c8afe14ef0:
A violent clash between Israel and Gaza was averted at the last minute on May 4.
Hamas pledged to prevent all rocket launches at Israel by various Palestinian factions in the Gaza Strip, whereas Israel promised to stop its airstrikes on the Strip and withdraw the military forces that had begun operating inside Gaza.
Israel had not responded to Hamas official Moussa Abu Marzouk’s statement as of the morning of May 5.
The latest escalation, including several mortars fired from Gaza to Israel over the past few weeks, was foreseeable.
Israeli defense officials have been telling Al-Monitor for weeks that Hamas was unlikely to put up with new Israeli limitations on the transfer of goods and raw materials through the Kerem Shalom crossing into Gaza.
Israel ordered restrictions on the number of trucks allowed through the Kerem Shalom crossing into Gaza, under pressure from residents of the Gaza border communities troubled by the heavy truck traffic.
Israel also announced that it would no longer allow cement into Gaza because Hamas was using it to build tunnels instead of rebuilding homes and infrastructure destroyed in Operation Protective Edge in 2014.
Hamas officials dismissed Israel’s claims, saying the entry of cement into the Strip is under close supervision, and Hamas has been adhering to the agreement struck at the end of Operation Protective Edge.
Hamas thinks Israel decided on a cement embargo after a tunnel was uncovered next to the Kerem Shalom crossing on April 18.
Defense Minister Moshe Ya'alon said Israel is not seeking a confrontation, "but if Hamas tries to challenge the State of Israel or disrupt the lives of Gaza border residents, it will be hit very hard.”
The IDF and Shin Bet security agency are closely monitoring the tunnel construction push on the northern and southern edges of Gaza, which is being carried out in broad daylight.
Hamas has been energetically rehabilitating its tunnel network destroyed during Operation Protective Edge.
The ongoing transfer of building material to Gaza enables Hamas to intensify its tunnel project.
Halting the passage of raw material will result in a flare-up of hostilities.
More than 1.8 million Palestinians live in Gaza.
Entire neighborhoods were destroyed during Operation Protective Edge and have not been rebuilt since.
The Gaza rehabilitation plan has been bogged down for a long time and the economic situation is deteriorating daily.
Hamas has dedicated all its energies to the removal of the siege on Gaza imposed in June 2007.
The Qassam rockets and mortar shells were always the means used by Hamas to bring Israel to the negotiating table and force it to discuss the easing of the blockade or its removal.
Hamas fired mortars at Israel to signal that additional economic pressure would lead to another major clash.
Israel must now accept the Turkish reconciliation proposal that includes a lifting of the Gaza blockade.
d5313f2808e03d59b9337360e6181816:
Hamas's leader in Gaza, Ismail Haniya, says Hamas is not seeking war with Israel but will resist Israeli incursions into the Palestinian enclave.
Three days of mortar and tank fire between Israel and Palestinian militants, as well as Israeli air strikes, have raised concerns of a new war in the Hamas-run territory.
Hamas accuses Israeli forces of intruding nearly 200 metres into Gazan territory.
Israeli aircraft carried out their fourth air raid on the enclave since Wednesday, attacking sites at Beit Lahiya in northern Gaza and near Khan Yunis in the south.
Since Wednesday, Hamas and other militant groups have fired at least 12 mortar rounds across the frontier, and Israeli tanks have fired repeatedly at what the army said were Hamas targets.
Zeina Al-Amour, a 54-year-old Palestinian woman, became the first fatality of the flare-up after Israeli tank fire hit her home.
Residents on both sides of the border said they were living in fear of a wider conflict.
Israel maintains a tight blockade on Gaza in what human rights groups say is collective punishment against its more than 1.8 million residents.
Hamas's armed wing, the Ezzedine al-Qassam Brigades, said on Friday that Israeli forces withdrew from positions inside the border east of Khan Yunis.
767e7f3c3db4226598ca9fafeb712c4b:
Hamas's deputy leader Ismail Haniyeh said that Hamas is not calling for a new war, but will not allow Israeli incursions or imposing facts on the ground in Gaza.
Hamas objects to the Israeli prohibition on Palestinian traffic in the "perimeter," a 300-meter buffer zone inside the Strip and bordering the frontier.
Hamas is in contact with Egypt, Qatar, Turkey and the UN's (Special Coordinator for Middle East Peace Process) Nickolay Mladenov to bring an end to the Israeli escalation.
Palestinian sources claimed that three IDF engineering vehicles passed through the security fence near Beit Hanoun, covered by two tanks.
The IDF is continuing its operation to locate tunnels used in other locations along the Strip's border.
Overnight, Palestinians fired a mortar shell at an area before Beit Lahia, but it exploded in Palestinian territory.
On Friday morning, Palestinians fired at least two mortars at IDF forces; there were no injuries.
The Israeli Air Force attacked targets in Gaza in response.
The IDF confirmed that the Israeli Air Force attacked targets in Gaza in response to the mortar fire.
The Palestinians reported that the Israelis targeted Hamas's military wing.
Hamas and Islamic Jihad in Gaza blamed Israeli entirely for the recent escalation in the Gaza Strip.
Hamas spokesman Mushir Al Masri warned Israel not to try the patience of Hamas and the other Palestinian factions.
a08dcf65bf5e94798c8d30d76895f144: Israeli tanks and army vehicles were on standby along the border with the Gaza Strip on Friday.
Renewed cross-border violence between the Israeli army and Hamas raised fears that conflict could flare for the first time since a devastating 2014 war.
e6112d59d39bc7c99f0823cc55a4579f: Deputy Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh said that Hamas is not calling for a new war but will not agree to intrusions and imposing facts in the Gaza Strip territory by the Israeli side.
Hamas is saying to a buffer zone inside the borders of Gaza and Israel has to understand this.
7fd0dfc270823adb1a7c0b74ae1e799a:
