Rhodes sought to mend ties with the press, writing that media outlets he worked with “vetted that deal as extensively as any other foreign policy initiative of the presidency.”
Rhodes insisted that top U.S. officials, such as Secretary of State John Kerry and Energy Secretary Ernest Moniz, deserve the credit for the completion of the Iran nuclear agreement.
2902204c93d4fb8eb0c6cdf9fe9997ca:
Ben Rhodes, Barack Obama's Assistant to the President and Deputy National Security Advisor for Strategic Communications and Speechwriting, oversaw the president's national security communications, speechwriting and global engagement.
Rhodes played a key role in selling the Iran nuclear deal, using manipulation and lies.
Obama and Rhodes lied about the start date of the negotiations with Iran and about the Iranians moderating.
Rhodes admitted that the US did not believe that those with whom the deal was made would moderate, but would likely stay what they were, the largest state sponsor of terrorism.
Rhodes said that the easiest way for the White House to shape the news is from the briefing podiums, each of which has its own dedicated press corps.
Rhodes created an echo chamber of freshly minted experts cheerleading for the deal.
Hillary Clinton came out in support of the Iran nuclear deal and even took some credit for it.
005a8a7d691305b25e96e009e25295c0:
Frederic C. Hof, Obama's former top Syria adviser, charged that the Obama administration's failure to protect Syrian civilians was because it was so intent on pursuing a nuclear agreement with Iran.
Hof countered that the Obama administration did not hesitate to intervene in Iraq and Syria to protect civilians from ISIS and Yazidis.
Hof explained that the Obama administration's fear and dismissal of making things better in Syria "by being there" applied only to those parts of Syria experiencing mass murder and massive displacement at the hands of Syrian president Bashar al-Assad.
David Samuels, the writer of the profile, explained that "by eliminating the fuss about Iran’s nuclear program, the administration hoped to eliminate a source of structural tension between the two countries, which would create the space for America to disentangle itself from its established system of alliances with countries like Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Israel and Turkey."
Hof credited Rhodes for spelling out Obama’s foreign policy framework so clearly, but suggested that the next administration turn to the "thoughtful (if fallible) and experienced (if imperfect) foreign policy practitioners—yes, the thoroughly disrespected ‘Blob’—to undo the damage they have done."
Richard Cohen of The Washington Post made a similar critique, stating that the Obama administration's foreign policy has resulted in Russia having more influence in the Middle East than the United States, and Iran and its proxies being everywhere.
3e633620b823d6577f6b91a026d73f68:
Congress has not passed any Iran-related bills since the nuclear deal took effect last year.
Lawmakers in both chambers and both parties are working on comprehensive legislation to punish Iran for its human-rights abuses, ballistic missile tests and other activities.
A bill to renew sanctions on Iran's energy sector has been bottled up in the Senate banking panel for the past 11 months despite bipartisan support for its passage.
Sen. Robert Menendez, D-N.J., and Sen. Bob Corker, R-Tenn., are working on broader sanctions legislation.
House members are also signaling their intentions to go after Iran with everything they can muster.
House Speaker Paul Ryan, R-Wis., wrote in a May 9 op-ed that House Republicans will present the country with an overarching vision for national security in the coming weeks.
House Foreign Affairs Committee Chairman Ed Royce, R-Calif., and ranking member Eliot Engel, D-N.Y., have been working on such legislation for several months.
Engel said he could support a stand-alone renewal of the Iran Sanctions Act, which lawmakers view as a vital backstop in case Iran cheats on its nuclear commitments under the JCPOA.
Sen. Ben Cardin, D-Md., said he supports renewing the Iran Sanctions Act and strengthening ballistic missile sanctions, but that the Republican leadership appears to want more.
The Senate voted 57-42 on an amendment to an energy spending bill by Sen. Tom Cotton, R-Ark., that would have prohibited the United States from buying heavy water from Iran.
070ede00352091e41d794749a92ff440:
The New York Times Magazine published an article on May 8, 2016, profiling Ben Rhodes, the president’s deputy national security adviser for strategic communications.
The article was written by David Samuels, an outspoken opponent of the Obama Iran negotiations.
Samuels presented himself as an open-eyed observer without acknowledging his own leanings.
Samuels spoke strongly against the nuclear talks during an April 2015 panel discussion at the conservative Hudson Institute.
Samuels published an essay on Slate.com in 2009 arguing the “rationality” of an Israeli air strike against Iran’s nuclear project.
The Times article has been delighting administration opponents with its inside account of how Rhodes tweaks the White House’s messages for willing and sometimes gullible journalists to share with the public.
Jeffrey Goldberg of The Atlantic and Laura Rozen of Al-Monitor are complaining to Silverstein that Samuels misrepresented them as administration shills without giving them a chance to reply.
Samuels writes that the Iran deal was sold to the American public through a “largely manufactured” narrative — namely, that Washington could work with Iran once it elected a “moderate” president, Hassan Rouhani, in 2013.
Samuels notes that the nuclear talks secretly began months before Rouhani’s election, when Mahmoud Ahmadinejad was still president.
Conservatives are now citing the article as proof that the nuclear deal was based on a pack of lies.
At least one, Illinois GOP Senator Mark Kirk, is calling for Rhodes’s resignation.
Samuels says that Rhodes’s passion is “his own sense of the urgency of radically reorienting American policy in the Middle East in order to make the prospect of American involvement in the region’s future wars a lot less likely.”
Samuels explains that Obama’s regional goals are to “eliminate a source of structural tension between the two countries, which would create the space for America to disentangle itself from its established system of alliances with countries like Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Israel and Turkey.”
bf03af868ec2abe4d3392ded955e1574:
The White House has refused to have deputy national security adviser Ben Rhodes testify over recent comments regarding the nuclear deal with Iran.
White House spokesman Josh Earnest said that GOP lawmakers should demand answers from their fellow Republicans instead of Rhodes.

Earnest said that the truth is what the administration has said about the Iran deal has come true.
Earnest did not specifically rule out Rhodes’s appearance in the Oversight Committee next week, though he strongly indicated that it would not happen.
The committee’s demands for Rhodes to testify at a hearing next Tuesday morning followed days of criticism for comments he made in a New York Times Magazine story.
In the article, Rhodes appeared contemptuous of journalists and prominent Washington foreign policy think tanks and boasted about creating an “echo chamber” of support for the nuclear deal with Iran.
The decision for him to participate in the story was made by multiple officials within the White House.
New York Times Magazine editor in chief Jake Silverstein defended the article and insisted that editors “stand behind the piece 100%.”
The Iran deal, which went into full effect earlier this year, sets limits on Iran’s ability to build a nuclear weapon in exchange for the lifting of international sanctions that have hampered Iran’s economy.
5dd73a799c6aa250acac747e00965c71:
Secretary of State John Kerry has been meeting with international banking and business leaders to drum up investment in Iran.
Tehran has a responsibility to clean up its financial act in order to attract investment on its own.

Companies will only be comfortable investing in Iran after they're assured those investments won't be used to support Hezbollah or help bolster the regime of Bashar Assad in Syria.
International banks don't want to unwittingly funnel money to Iran's ballistic missile program, but any financial transaction with Iran risks funding Iran's ongoing illicit activities.
The U.S. shouldn't be in a position of "rehabilitating Iran" and should be reinforcing the effect and the reach of its authorities around the world.
Most major banks in Europe and elsewhere are biding their time to discover what pitfalls investing in Iran carries with it.
The U.S. policy-makers and their European counterparts should publicly identify Iran's "self-imposed banking problems," including its financial system's involvement in funding terrorism.
The Obama administration wants "to fulfill our responsibility to international financial institutions" and provide specific guidance on what U.S. and international sanctions laws allow when it comes to doing business with Iran.

Sen. Mark Kirk (R-Ill.) believes that the Obama administration’s case against Sen. Bob Menendez (D-N.J.) is politically motivated.

b240e07ffff2c710620a416dec94d774:
The Obama administration misled the American people about the timing and nature of negotiations with Iran, claiming that negotiations began after the election of "moderate" Hassan Rouhani when they were already underway.
The administration's goal was to avoid a divisive debate over its policy choices and to create space for the United States to disengage from the Middle East.
The administration used a "war room" and an "echo chamber" to control the narrative and suppress negative comments about the Iran deal.
The administration's actions have divided Democrats and Republicans, leading to the withdrawal of amendments seeking to prohibit the use of federal funds to purchase Iran's overproduced heavy water.
The administration's withdrawal from the Middle East has boosted Iran's influence and left a mess that will need to be cleaned up by the next President.
0fd12160536b6243564a3ccd3369f999:
The Ploughshares Fund, a group that supports nuclear disarmament, gave National Public Radio (NPR) $100,000 last year to help report on the Iran nuclear deal and related issues.
Ploughshares has funded NPR's coverage of national security since 2005, with at least $700,000 in funding over that time.
Ploughshares' backing is unusual, given its prominent role in the debate over the Iran deal.
Ploughshares has also funded other media organizations, including the Arms Control Association, the Brookings Institution, the Atlantic Council, J-Street, the National Iranian American Council, and Princeton University.

2abbd55ff1b393e46ce3646b241c7735:

Lawmakers on both sides of the aisle have accused the administration of a bait-and-switch to help sell the nuclear deal to Congress.

cb01f6d47ce711b6023e574ab5034802:
Ploughshares Fund was at the center of an echo chamber that promoted the Iran deal.

Ploughshares Fund boasted of contributing to "building the narrative across the country" by publishing "nearly 1,400 pro-diplomacy op-eds, letters to the editor and editorials" during critical moments of the Iran campaign.
The National Council of Resistance of Iran (NCRI) and its biggest component, the Mujahedin-e Khalq (MEK), provided the lion's share of sensitive information about Iran's nuclear program.
The NCRI revealed the Natanz and Arak secret sites in 2002, triggering inspections by the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA).
The NCRI disclosed the construction of the underground enrichment facility, Fordow, near Qom in December 2005.
The U.S. Government has conceded the Iranian opposition's crucial role in exposing Iran's nuclear program.
After Hassan Rouhani became president of Iran in mid-2013, the Obama administration became dismissive of the NCRI's non-conforming information about Iran's nuclear program.
The NCRI revealed details about suspicious activities in a military site called Parchin in 2014, but the Obama administration never investigated.
The NCRI revealed details of a site in Tehran where the regime conducted secret research involving advanced nuclear enrichment centrifuges in 2015, but the State Department spokeswoman said they had "no information at this time to support the conclusion of the report."
The Obama administration discarded non-conforming realities as nuisances in order to maintain "the narrative" that supported the Iran deal.
d4773fc1c04b791bfd9604ce89920e73:
National Public Radio (NPR) ombudsman Elizabeth Jensen suggested NPR consider avoiding grants like the one from Ploughshares Fund for coverage of the Iran nuclear agreement.

Ploughshares gave NPR a $100,000 grant last year to support "national security reporting that emphasizes the themes of US nuclear weapons policy and budgets, Iran’s nuclear program, international nuclear security topics and US policy toward nuclear security."
Ploughshares also funded reporters and partnerships with other news outlets.
NPR ombudsman Elizabeth Jensen said no coverage was skewed and "NPR did not accept money to report favorably on the Iran deal. There was no pay for play."

NPR is reviewing its disclosure safeguards.
Ploughshares started supporting NPR in 1984 and has given $700,000 in grants to NPR over the last decade.
Jensen examined 254 on-air newsmagazine stories about the Iran deal since 2015 and found almost half were "neutral," about the negotiations or the agreement’s later implementation.
NPR spoke twice each to Obama and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, a leading opponent, and many congressional critics.
NPR canceled a scheduled August interview with Rep. Mike Pompeo, R-Kan., a critic of the Iran deal, because it had too many other interviews booked.
Outside groups of all stripes are increasingly giving money to news organizations for special projects or general news coverage.
b8a5b73aed36a8bebde243b7b78ab047:

The State Department admitted that it had doctored the video of a 2013 press briefing in which former spokeswoman Jen Psaki seemed to suggest that the administration was misleading Americans about whether secret talks with Iran were underway.

The State Department’s annual Country Reports on Terrorism for 2015 cited Iran’s direct attacks on ISIS and its support of groups seeking to destroy the Islamic State as evidence of Iran’s terrorist activities.

Israel has imposed a trade blockage on the Palestinians since 2007.

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu expressed his regret for the attack in 2013, and it has taken three years to normalize diplomatic relations.
The agreement was brokered with the help of the US.
Under the deal, Israel will agree to Turkey's humanitarian presence in Gaza, which among other things involves the completion of a hospital in the Palestinian enclave and the construction of a new power station as well as a plant for desalination of water.
Israel rendered an apology and will also pay $20 million in compensation to a special fund dedicated to the families of the victims killed by the IDF soldiers.
Turkey agreed to pass a law that would put an end to lawsuits from the families of the victims killed in the raid.
Turkey demanded that Israel lift the Gaza blockade, but Israel refused to fulfill this condition.
785d69ead96d3ad3f1530c177d8d1ea3:
The first Turkish ship carrying humanitarian aid to Gaza arrived at the port of Ashdod on Sunday afternoon, one week after Israel and Turkey signed a reconciliation agreement.
The ship contained food, medicine and toys which will be transferred into the coastal strip following a security check by Israeli authorities.
Dozens demonstrated at the Kerem Shalom crossing against transferring the goods into Gaza and the arrival of the Turkish ship in particular, and attempted to block the passage of trucks and goods.
The parents of Oron Shaul, Erez Sagi and Avrah Mangisto, who are held in Hamas captivity, have vowed to continue to protest and block humanitarian aid shipments into Gaza as long as their son’s body are held in Hamas captivity.
The parents of Oron Shaul said that to allow humanitarian aid into Gaza from Turkey constitutes the forfeiting of IDF soldiers and that "There is nothing more humanitarian than releasing the captured bodies of our sons in exchange for giving benefits to Gaza. It needs to be two concurrent humanitarian gestures."
c039f55186b2e5f8905bbe2c81840df4:
Turkey has sent food, medicine and clothes to Gaza via the Israeli port of Ashdod, as part of its rapprochement with Israel.
The move comes six years after a deadly raid by Israeli commandos on another Turkish aid ship.
Turkey and Israel reconcile after months of negotiations, which included compensation for the victims of the Israeli raid.
Tel Aviv will contribute $20 million (18 million euros) to a victims' fund for those killed in the so-called Mavi Marmara affair.
In return, Ankara will drop criminal charges against the Israeli soldiers involved in the raid.
Israel has agreed to allow aid shipments to Hamas-run Gaza, as long as they first pass through the Ashdod port for inspection.
Turkey will also be allowed to build a hospital, power plant and water desalinization plant in Gaza.
A small number of Israelis protested the shipments outside the port, demanding the return of the remains of two Israeli soldiers killed in the 2014 Gaza war.
The aid delivery comes before the start of one of Islam's major holidays - Eid al-Fitr.
70bb7bd4c7fd2111bf391ae82ee850e6:
Turkish aid arrived in the Gaza Strip on Monday via Israel, after the two countries restored ties frozen over a deadly Israeli raid on a Gaza-bound Turkish ship in 2010.
The aid includes food parcels, toys and children's clothing and shoes.
The aid will be distributed to those most in need by the Hamas deputy minister of social affairs along with the Turkish and Palestinian Red Crescent societies.
Turkey had initially pushed for a lifting of Israel's years-long blockade of Gaza as part of the negotiations to normalise ties, but Israel rejected this.
A compromise was eventually reached allowing Turkey to send aid through Ashdod rather than directly to the Palestinian enclave.
Turkey's ruling Islamic-rooted AKP party has friendly ties with Gaza's Hamas rulers, and President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has been a vocal supporter of the Palestinian cause.
Turkey and Israel were formerly close regional allies, but fell out in 2010 when Israeli commandos killed 10 Turkish activists in a raid on a flotilla seeking to run the blockade.
Under the reconciliation deal, Israel will pay $20 million in compensation to the families of those killed.
0e7bde39fb143b8f585e186c45ab438e:
Turkey has sent its first aid shipment to the Gaza Strip in six years after the country struck a reconciliation deal with Israel.
The Lady Leyla ship—carrying 11,000 tons of humanitarian aid including food, clothing and toys—docked at the Israeli port of Ashdod.
The cargo will be unloaded and transported overland to Gaza in time for the Muslim feast of Eid al-Fitr, which marks the end of Ramadan on Tuesday.
Turkey has not sent an aid ship to Gaza since 2010 followed an incident when Israeli naval forces boarded a Turkish flotilla, killing nine Turkish activists.
The incident caused a freeze in diplomatic relations between the two countries, but the pair signed a deal to restore relations on Tuesday.
It includes Israel paying $20 million in compensation to Turkish families affected by the flotilla raid and allows Turkey to send aid to and carry out infrastructure projects in Gaza.
Turkey and Israel will also appoint ambassadors.
Israeli spokesperson Oren Rosenblatt said the ship's arrival was "an immediate implementation of the agreement" and that the Israeli government was making a "special effort" to ensure the aid reaches Gaza in time for Eid.
Gaza's 2-million population is mostly Muslim.
The Gaza Strip, controlled by Islamist group Hamas, has been under blockade by Israel since 2006 after an Israeli soldier was abducted by Hamas.
The blockade has been criticized by the United Nations, with outgoing Secretary General Ban Ki-moon saying Tuesday during a visit to Palestine that it "suffocates its [Gaza's] people, stifles it economy and impedes reconstruction efforts."
Israel says the blockade is necessary, however, to prevent Hamas from receiving military materials.
Hamas currently uses a network of underground tunnels to smuggle materials into the coastal enclave.
f7c7249912236fad55a6b5957c1d8110:
Israel will allow Turkey to transfer funds to banks in the Gaza strip if activities are approved by Israel and the Palestinian Authority.
The agreement was signed by Ministry of Foreign Affairs director general Dore Gold and approved by the security cabinet.
Israel has committed to transfer $20 million to Turkey to compensate the bereaved families from the Mave Marmara Gaza flotilla incident in 2010.
fd8c536e2ccb089fa797a131e871c987:
First trucks of Turkish aid arrive in Gaza via Israel, a week after Turkey and Israel mended ties.
About 500 trucks carrying toys, diapers, clothes, medicine and food entered Gaza on Monday after a security check in Israel.
Turkey would provide "continuous, regular humanitarian assistance" for Gaza.
The delivery comes in time for Wednesday's Eid al-Fitr holiday marking the end of the Muslim holy month of Ramadan.
Israel imposed a blockade on the Gaza Strip in 2006 after Hamas abducted an Israeli soldier.
United Nations Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon called the blockade "collective punishment for which there must be accountability."
a7acd64c441e816dc50f5b09fc7948c1:
The Land Authority in the Gaza Strip is proceeding with the second phase of a scheme to hand government-owned lands to Hamas government employees who have not been paid since 2013.
The Palestinian consensus government, formed in 2014, refused to recognize Hamas government employees in Gaza as civil servants and therefore pay them.
In the first phase of the program, 49 plots across Gaza were given to government employees.
Some 40,000 Gaza government employees are expected to be paid with land.
Lawyer Bakr Turkmani said that Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas is the only party with the authority to issue decisions to privatize government-owned lands in the public interest.
d8e09cd2c3c4a75dfd402d5026349467:
A delegation from Turkey's Energy and Natural Resources Ministry is visiting the Gaza Strip to discuss ways to meet the coastal enclave's electricity needs.
The visit comes two weeks after Ankara and Tel-Aviv agreed to normalise relations following a six-year hiatus.
The delegation will meet both Israeli and Palestinian officials to discuss how to resolve Gaza's energy crisis.
Gaza continues to suffer from a severe energy crisis that has forced the local authorities to adopt a rotation system, cutting power in certain parts of the Strip in order to supply electricity to other areas.
The Turkish delegation is expected to provide a report on its findings to Energy and Natural Resources Minister Berat Albayrak.
Since 2007, the Gaza Strip has been under a strict Israeli and internationally backed siege that has deprived the enclave's roughly 1.9 million inhabitants of their most basic needs, especially food, fuel, medicine and construction supplies.
2e0174a827cfc8c5e399e1260867ab7d:
Turkey will ready another aid ship to Gaza before the Eid-al-Adha holiday in September.
A Turkish aid ship carrying 11,000 tons of supplies for the Gaza Strip arrived at Israel’s Ashdod port on July 3.
The Panama-flagged Lady Leyla delivered 10,000 toys and 10,000 packages of food and aid for children in Gaza.
Turkey and Israel froze their ties in 2010 after Israeli troops stormed the Gaza-bound Mavi Marmara aid ship in international waters, killing 10 Turkish activists.
Israel agreed that Turkey will be the coordinating country in delivering humanitarian aid to Gaza.
Under the deal reached between Turkey and Israel, Israel will pay $20 million in compensation to the families of the Mavi Marmara victims.
4545fa4abb4a3d022d9673eb09a71a19:
Israel and Turkey signed an agreement to normalize diplomatic relations, allowing Turkey to lead efforts to build a seawater desalination plant and power station in Gaza.
Gaza has no modern sewage treatment plants, and its untreated sewage pollutes the aquifer that it shares with Israel.
An estimated 90 million liters of raw sewage from Gaza flow into the Mediterranean Sea every day, polluting not only the shared coastline but also threatening Israel's desalination plant in Ashkelon.
Every Palestinian city in the West Bank emits sewage into streams that either flow west into Israel or east towards the Jordan River and the Dead Sea.
About 50 billion liters of untreated West Bank sewage pollute shared groundwater, including the Mountain and Coastal Aquifers, as well as Israel's Mediterranean beaches.
Some 1.8 million Palestinians in Gaza have run out of drinking water due to pollution and over-extraction.
Water shortages in many West Bank Palestinian towns and cities are even worse than in Gaza.
Israel is the world leader in wastewater treatment and reuse, and a world leader in desalination.
Israel enjoys a substantial water surplus and can increase supplies to the Palestinians without cutting water allocations to Israelis.
A new agreement is needed to manage water and sanitation across the West Bank and Gaza, in the interests of both peoples.
6ab78c27d0324b1d777648fa994c0197:
Turkey is taking steps to help Gaza resolve its 10-year-old electricity crisis after failing to persuade Israel to lift its siege on the Gaza Strip.
Turkey pledged to provide an economic projects package to Palestinians that includes establishing a power plant in Gaza in exchange for normalizing relations with Israel in June.
A delegation of eight Turkish energy experts arrived in Gaza on July 12 to be briefed on the electricity crisis and to study proposed solutions.
The Turkish delegation suggested sending an electricity vessel to Gaza's shores, but Israel has yet to respond.
The Turkish project to generate electricity in Gaza has begun to be implemented on the ground, and several Turkish officials and experts have arrived to inspect the problem and study the proposed solutions.
The project will take a year or two to be fully implemented, and the responsibility lies on the shoulders of the Israelis, who might seek to put a spoke in the wheel of implementation.
The electricity problem in Gaza emerged in 2006 when Israel bombed and destroyed parts of Gaza's only power plant, causing a blackout in the majority of cities and camps and depriving more than 700,000 citizens of electricity for many days.
The PA has made several proposals to the Turkish delegation, some of which are instant solutions and other strategic, in a bid to overcome the electricity crisis.
The Turkish delegation has been studying the possibility of expanding and repairing the current power plant.
The electricity bill in the Gaza Strip is the highest in the world, standing at 0.6 kwh per 1 shekel [about 26 cents].
Gazans, who have become fed up with the electricity problem, are no longer buying any talks about solutions to the crisis until they are effectively implemented.
abecb0e9c2e48fe914a58641294aa640:
Qatar has pledged to pay one-month salaries for public sector employees in Gaza to help “alleviate the suffering” caused by the Israeli blockade.
The Emir of Qatar, Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad Al-Thani, has ordered paying a total of 113 million rials ($31 million), which is the total wage bill for one month in the strip ruled by Hamas.
Gaza has been subjected to a stringent Israeli blockade since 2006, with construction materials tightly controlled for fear militants could make use of them to forge arms or build fortifications.
Hamas hired more than 40,000 people after it seized Gaza in 2007 following deadly clashes with militants of Fatah, the party of Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas.
d38681a5373c36fb3c0154bae77ae149:
A European Parliament delegation visited EU-funded infrastructure projects in the water sector in the Gaza Strip on Thursday.
The delegation was headed by Jean Arthuis, a French lawmaker and head of the EU budget committee, and included Ralph Tarraf, the EU representative in Palestine.
The delegation visited a wastewater treatment plant in northern Gaza Strip which is funded by the European Union, the World Bank, Belgium, France and Sweden and a small desalination plant in south Gaza.
An agreement was signed with the management of the desalination plant to raise its productive capacity.
Deputy Chairman of the Water Authority in Gaza Rabhi al-Sheikh described the water and sewage projects that are funded by the EU and other donors as "an important lever to address the water crisis in Gaza".
Al-Sheikh praised European support for such projects and noted their importance to the people of Gaza.
5d352fc9a31c96127331901a920d44a9:
Hamas' former prime minister, Ismail Haniyeh, thanked Qatar for paying the salaries of Hamas employees in the Gaza Strip.
Israel has reportedly approved Qatar's request to pay Hamas employees, despite previously opposing such a move.
Israel's approval of the Qatari payment is seen as a recognition and perpetuation of the Hamas government.
Hamas is preparing to participate in municipal elections in the West Bank and Gaza, and its rising star could lead to significant gains.
The Israeli government's decision to allow the Qatari payment reduces the chance of war in Gaza in the near term.
eceb18ffc97a5326722fd5899cf3e696:
The Palestinian Ministry of Social Affairs began the second stage of distributing Turkish humanitarian aid to 30,000 poor families in the blockaded Gaza Strip.
The first stage of aid distribution benefited 11,000 poor families in Gaza.
A third stage of aid distribution will be organized in upcoming weeks.
The Gaza Strip has groaned under a joint Israeli-Egyptian blockade since 2007.
A Turkish aid ship docked in Israel's port of Ashdod on July 3, carrying 11,000 tons of humanitarian aid destined for Gaza.
The influx of Turkish aid to Gaza comes within the context of a deal signed last month between Ankara and Tel Aviv in which the two agreed to restore diplomatic relations following a six-year hiatus.
Tel Aviv has met all of Ankara's preconditions for normalizing ties, which were severed in 2010 after Israeli commandos stormed a Turkish aid vessel bound for Gaza.
The attack led to the death of nine Turkish activists and left another 30 injured, one of whom succumbed to his injuries nearly four years later.
Turkey had demanded that Israel officially apologize for the attack, compensate the families of those killed, and lift its longstanding blockade of the Gaza Strip.
In 2013, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu voiced his regret to Turkey's then-prime minister (now president) Recep Tayyip Erdoğan over the incident.
Under the terms of last month's agreement, the two countries will exchange ambassadors and Israel will pay $20 million in compensation to the families of the 2010 flotilla attack victims.
Israel has also agreed to Turkey's request to maintain a "humanitarian presence" in the blockaded Gaza Strip.
efaacdd8e41b05ac4966dc601da659e6:
Hamas is distributing land to 40,000 civil servants loyal to the group to compensate for unpaid salaries.

The land giveaway allows each group of four Hamas employees to share a 500-square-meter plot that they can either build on or sell.

Hamas is using some of its new revenue to fund summer camps and communal evening meals during Ramadan.
Turkey has sent an aid ship to Gaza and a delegation to explore Gaza's energy crisis and outline possible solutions.
6ad9530bdf7b5d3c87c5c063704787db:
A mobile library has been sent to Gaza to encourage children to read, visiting 40 neighborhoods this year.

The mobile library is equipped with tables, seats, and a storyteller who tells children stories.
The mobile library is expected to return to the West Bank by the end of August after completing its three-month tour.
The Gaza Strip contains just 15 public libraries, due to a lack of space.
Religious institutions in Gaza often provide small libraries, but most of the books there are religious.
The Brighter Tomorrow Cultural Center in Jabaliya is the only library in the area, but it is very small and has an inventory of approximately 600 books, mostly religious.
570b79e54b9852aef2da1f9877caf42d:
Senior Hamas leader in Gaza Ismail Haniyeh is working to ensure money sent to the terror group by Qatar will be used to pay “military personnel” alongside civilian government employees.
Qatar agreed to transfer some 113 Saudi riyal ($31 million) to Hamas to pay the salaries of the group’s employees in the Strip.
Hamas employees have generally been receiving a third to half of their salaries over the past three years.
Haniyeh is in contact with various “government agencies” in Gaza to support the payment of the group’s “military personnel” with the Qatari money.
Haniyeh lashed out against “parties” in Gaza who attempt to distinguish between the military and civilian branches of the organization.
Haniyeh demanded that both military and civilians are considered “legitimate” employees who are “appointed by the decision of a legitimate government.”
Israel and most Western governments consider Hamas a terror organization.
The UN, however, has attempted to differentiate between the Islamist group’s political and military wing, known as the Izz ad-Din al-Qassam Brigades.
The Qatari payment came after Israel agreed to the emirate’s request to pay Hamas employees.
62aa5d15259041aebed379a2e5959bbb:
Saudi Arabia has cut oil prices to Asia by $1.60 per barrel, the most in 10 months.
Saudi Arabia is ramping up exports to regain market share starting September.
Iran has managed to become OPEC's third-biggest producer since January when international sanctions restricting its exports were lifted.
Saudi Arabia has responded by increasing exports of its oil and refined products.
Demand for crude in Asia is currently slowing with refineries cutting production due to a slump in margins and constantly rising supply from state-owned corporations.
Since the start of the year Brent crude rose 17 percent as a result of supply disruptions in Nigeria and Canada.
Crude prices have slipped in the last three months and are still 12 percent lower compared to a year ago.
Oil Minister Bijan Namdar Zanganeh said in an interview with Iranian state television on Monday that "The oil market is oversupplied now but there are expectations that there will be a balance between demand and supply in the market."
7f5f8c3dc28f21ce25495f16a67f4381:
Saudi Arabia has cut oil prices to Asia by $1.60 per barrel, the most in 10 months.
Saudi Arabia is ramping up exports to regain market share.
Iran has boosted crude output 25 percent in 2016 aiming to reach daily production of four million barrels by the end of the year.
Iran has managed to become OPEC's third-biggest producer since January when international sanctions restricting its exports were lifted.
Saudi Arabia has responded by increasing exports of its oil and refined products.
Demand for crude in Asia is currently slowing with refineries cutting production due to a slump in margins and constantly rising supply from state-owned corporations.

f79fe0da012b9859ae1be9d636de3533:
Saudi Aramco, the world’s largest oil exporter, lowered the pricing terms for Arab Light crude sold to Asia by the most in 10 months.
Saudi Aramco will sell cargoes of Arab Light in September at $1.10 a barrel below Asia’s regional benchmark, a pricing cut of $1.30 from August.
Saudi Aramco is not worried about rival producers, such as Iraq, Iran and Russia, gaining ground in key market Asia.
Iran’s oil production has increased by 600,000 barrels per day since January 16, 2016, and the government plans to raise it up to 800,000 b/d by the summer of 2016.
Saudi Arabia produced 10.308 million barrels per day of oil in June compared to 10.242 million barrels per day in May.
9cd14e2f9de004fe665c50360d041c84:
Saudi Arabia pumped 10.67 million barrels of oil per day (bpd) in July, its biggest monthly output.
Saudi Arabia's previous production high was 10.56 million (bpd) in June 2015.
Saudi Arabia is one of the few countries across the globe to burn crude oil for electricity.
Global oil prices declined almost 15 percent in July over concerns oversupply of crude and finished products would delay the rebalancing of the market.
OPEC will meet in September at a conference in Algiers to continue talks on stabilizing the market.
In April, the talks on a production freeze between Russia, OPEC and other oil producers collapsed after Saudi Arabia demanded rival Iran to be part of the deal.
On Tuesday, Iran said its exports have regained 2.5 million bpd, last seen before sanctions were imposed on Tehran over its nuclear program.
8c7d8474bc80eb2e0a872e94da34443e:
Saudi Arabia and Iran are not giving ground in their market share war.
Saudi Arabia boosted oil output to a record 10.67 million barrels a day in July.
Iran’s oil output is up to 3.85 million barrels a day, the highest since 2008.
Saudi Arabia is engaged in a battle for market share with rival Iran and has cut prices to its customers in Asia.

Opec’s smaller producers could only look on as prices tumbled more than 50 per cent since mid 2014.
The last effort to freeze output in April, which also included non-Opec producer Russia, collapsed after Saudi Arabia demanded that Iran be part of the deal.
Iran still opposes any limits on its production, with the country seeking to reclaim its pre-sanctions share of Opec’s total output before contributing to any production freeze.
7fe9de5d375da4cdce60aa3c0ebe2850:
Russia is consulting with Saudi Arabia and other producers to achieve oil market stability.
Russia is open for more discussions on freezing output levels if needed.

Russia is ready to achieve the widest possible level of coordination and put in place joint measures to achieve oil market stability.

An informal meeting of major producing countries is scheduled in Algeria late next month.
OPEC members will meet on the sidelines of the International Energy Forum (IEF) in Algeria from Sept. 26-28.

Talks on a global oil production level freeze collapsed in April.

d8217993ccd32e9700e89310b52bd319:
Saudi Arabia signals it may hit a new oil output record in August, surpassing Russia as the world's top oil producer.
Saudi Arabia has been raising production since June to meet rising seasonal domestic demand and higher exports requirements.
Saudi Arabia pumped 10.67 million barrels of oil per day in July, the highest in its history.
Saudi Arabia is expected to raise its crude supplies to a further record this month, with output potentially reaching 10.8-10.9 million bpd.
Saudi Energy Minister Khalid al-Falih explained the July production increase was due to rising seasonal domestic demand and increased customer demand worldwide.
Saudi Arabia drew down additional barrels from its huge inventories to supply 10.75 million bpd of crude to the market in July.
OPEC and non-OPEC producers are expected to revive talks on freezing output next month in Algeria.

232efbd625cbbb3a4d214e477d875fe2:

65c61c51a21041c127a18a03c867277f:
Iran signals more willingness to support joint action to boost oil price.

Iran will attend talks between the world's biggest oil producers in Algeria in September.

Iran will attend OPEC talks in Algeria in September.
Iran has been increasing oil production after the rollback of Western sanctions in January, aiming to reach four million barrels per day.

Lebanon is aware of the accusations against it and insists that they are devoid of any truths.
The LAF Commander, General Jean Qahwaji, is adamant on honouring its commitments and has repeatedly called on the rank and file to depoliticise the armed forces.
Lebanon is caught between Israel and Syria, who agree on regime stability in Damascus, though at Beirut's expense.
f9a7d8f074f3a4ed6deb8f0ec4dc3880:
The Syrian civil war has resulted in an estimated half million deaths over four years, with no end in sight.
Aleppo, a city with a pre-war population of 2.3 million, has been heavily damaged, with estimates of 30-40 thousand dead and 100,000 refugees.
Israel has provided medical care to injured fighters and civilians who have reached the border, and has bombed in response to shells landing on Israeli territory.
The Jerusalem Post has called on Israel to take a more active role in helping civilians in Aleppo, but the government's response has been limited.
Israel benefits from the ongoing conflict in Syria, as it keeps its enemies busy and distracts the international community from the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
Israel is monitoring the situation in Syria and is prepared to take action if necessary to protect its interests.
There is a high level of pathos among Israel's Arabs and Muslims over the conflict in Syria, as they see their people being torn apart.
Russia and the United States are the main external actors involved in the conflict, with Russia supporting Assad's forces and the US providing limited support to rebel groups.
23557d41a2b7f0a3624d9651cfaad3b5:
Eli Cohen, an Israeli spy, was brutally tortured and publicly hanged in Syria.
Judy Feld Carr organized the rescue of over 3,000 Syrian Jews from persecution and imprisonment.
The author initially felt tempered in their response to the Syrian civil war due to the past treatment of Jews in Syria.
The author's Jewish upbringing and values, which emphasize the sanctity of life, led them to condemn the atrocities committed by the Syrian regime.
The author expresses gratitude for their Jewish heritage, which has instilled in them a strong sense of humanity.
795b6bdc769bcb584dc31d6a65561399:
Israel has stopped distributing gas masks to its civilians since early 2014 due to an international deal to disarm Syria of its chemical weapons stockpiles.
The issue of chemical weapons has resurfaced due to the Syrian civil war and the threat from Hezbollah and the Islamic State.
In August 2013, the Assad regime deployed chemical weapons against the neighborhood of Ghouta near Damascus, killing over a thousand civilians.
Under the terms of the brokered deal, Syria’s chemical weapons would be shipped out of the country and destroyed by international monitors.
In April 2014, reports surfaced that the Assad regime was hiding parts of its chemical weapons stockpile as a deterrent against rebel forces.
In December 2016, Israeli Defense Minister Avigdor Lieberman stated that Israel would prevent the smuggling of advanced weapons, military equipment, and weapons of mass destruction from Syria to Hezbollah.
Hezbollah holding strategic weapons is a problem not just for Israel but the region and the entire Western world.
ISIS has deployed crude chemical weapons on the battlefields of Syria and Iraq 52 times since 2014.
In late November 2016, ISIS fighters fired on an IDF border patrol on the Syrian side of the Golan Heights bordering Israel.
Israel is taking notice of the use of chemical weapons in Iraq by ISIS and is making it clear that it is taking notice.
The Israeli Defense Forces have an elite engineering unit tasked with defending Israel against the use of chemical weapons.
037a3e375b15169a06c7e729b64f500c:
Iran and Turkmenistan are in a dispute over gas prices, with Turkmenistan threatening to stop the gas flow if Iran does not settle a $1.8 billion debt.
Turkmenistan claims Iran owes it $1.8 billion from sales between 2007 and 2008 when freezing winters led to severe shortages across 20 Iranian provinces.
Iran holds the world’s biggest gas reserves but they are mostly located in the country’s south, making the country reliant on its neighbors for supplies in the northern provinces.
Iran currently imports about 35-40 million cubic meters a day of gas from Turkmenistan under a deal which has stood for the past 20 years.
Minister of Petroleum Bijan Zangeneh has announced that if Turkmens insisted on halting the gas flow, Iran would stop its energy dealings with the country.
Turkmenistan is a landlocked nation and its shipment of gas to international markets has to go through the neighbors, including Iran.
655d6ca9edc4a17daff323cca541ecb6:
Iran's Majlis (Parliament) Energy Commission member Ali Adiani urges Iran to stop depending on other countries for gas imports.
Iran has the largest gas reserves in the region and should meet its gas demands from its own resources.
Turkmenistan, which provides gas to parts of northern Iran, demanded illogically high prices for its gas exports.
Iran informed Turkmenistan that it will no longer accept any demands out of the previously made agreements between the two sides.
On December 30, Iranian representatives in Turkmenistan were told to leave the negotiating table due to Turkmenistan's demands.
Iran was ready to declare its decision to cut gas imports from Turkmenistan when Ashkhabad gave in to Tehran's demands.
Turkmenistan has agreed to continue its gas exports to northern Iran.
Turkmenistan had asked to receive a 1.8-billion-dollar debt from Iran, a claim that was not confirmed by the Iranian side.
8950cd39bf53bf2128748a5b0c72da63:
The Iranian government has ratified a new policy for pricing natural gas distributed across the country.
The Cabinet has ordered the National Gas Company to set the price of natural gas at 1,500 rials ($0.04) per cubic meter in the first eight months of the Iranian calendar year (March 20 to November 20).
The incremental system of pricing, whereby customers in the housing, trade and production sectors had to pay more per cubic meter of gas as the volume of consumption rose, will be revoked.
In the incremental system, which according to the new decision will be applied only in the four cold months of the year, each cubic meter of gas will cost 400 rials in the first-stage consumption (the lowest consumption).
For the tenth-stage consumption (the highest level of consumption considered by the law), each cubic meter of gas will cost 4,800 rials.
20c100b57ce8f90e5202fd7f01c012da:
Iran denounced Turkmenistan for abruptly cutting off gas supplies despite ongoing talks on debt settlement.
Iran and Turkmenistan had reached an agreement on debt settlement after prolonged negotiations.
Turkmenistan cut off gas supplies to Iran on Sunday without prior notice, leaving Iran unaffected in feeding its national gas grid.
Iran has imported natural gas from Turkmenistan since 1997 for distribution in the north of the country.
Turkmenistan has a history of raising gas prices during wintertime, including a nine-fold increase demand in 2006.
7ca4dcd7cdc9f0ee9cb5c827427751e9:
Iranian Oil Minister Bijan Namdar Zanganeh said that the National Iranian Gas Company (NIGC) and Turkmen state company Turkmengas should resolve the “commercial dispute” over outstanding debts for previous natural gas sales themselves.
Iranian Oil Minister Bijan Namdar Zanganeh expressed considerable reluctance to link the gas dispute between Iran and Turkmenistan to diplomatic issues.
Reuters citing Turkmen Foreign Ministry reported Jan. 3 that Turkmenistan has limited natural gas supplies to Iran since Jan. 1 over unpaid past deliveries.
The Iranian Foreign Ministry has also expressed the country’s disinclination to turn the gas dispute into a diplomatic issue.
0c1ccb4066230ebf0f4ef3448b5f0057:
Iran increased gas production to compensate for the halt in supplies from Turkmenistan.
Iran's gas production has been increased more than 50 percent over the past three years.
Iran's central regions increased gas production to 300 million cubic meters of gas per day to compensate for Turkmenistan gas halt.
Turkmenistan cut exports of natural gas to Iran on grounds that Iran should make a rapid payment of the debts that remained from past sales.
Iran's Ministry of Petroleum criticized Turkmenistan's move as "illogical".
2b97ebdfc9744a68e5c5fd3239b05704:
Iran will resume electricity export to Iraq within one month.
Iran stopped electricity export to Iraq because the related contract expired.
An Iranian delegation has traveled to Iraq to discuss extending the electricity export deal.
Iran was exporting 700-1,000 MW of electricity to Iraq under the previous contract.
Iraq owes Iran some $1 billion for electricity import.
The two sides earlier agreed that the debts will be cleared in 10 installments, but no installment has been paid so far.
Oil price fall which has led to sharp fall in Iraqi administration’s revenues is main reason behind the delay.
Iran exported 9.88 billion kWh of electricity last fiscal year (ended March 2016), of which 69.1 percent went to Iraq.
802c21d1419b5dc389900d5ec4a13ebe:
An Iranian delegation has travelled to Iraq to extend the electricity sale contract.
The halt in electricity exports to Iraq was due to the expiry of the contract.
The new agreement needs to be modified in accordance with current circumstances and the changes in currency prices.
An Iranian delegation, comprising Tavanir deputies, have been deployed to Iraq to conduct negotiations on setting new provisions in the contract.
The Iranian and Iraqi sides always worked together even though the Iranian team would hold talks with Iraqis on revenue collection procedures.
The cut in electricity exports was caused merely because the period of contract was over.
The Iraqi power grid did not allow room for a boost in Iran’s electricity export.
Iran’s domestic consumption would rise in summer which again would make it impossible to augment export figures.
Presently, an average of 700 to 1000 megawatts of electricity are being exported to Iraq.
Exports to Iraq will be restarted in one month’s time.
33fa9d271829b35e48c9931dafc79b0f: Iran has signed agreements with five international companies on the development of the Azadegan oil field in the west of the country.
Iran has been looking to attract international investors since the lifting of international sanctions in January last year.
b725ffd80f091d062417bd225eec719b:
Iran has prioritized development of Tous gas field, the second upstream gas project after Khangiran in the country’s north-eastern part.
Iran projects to produce 4 million cubic meters per day (mcm/d) of gas from Tous field.
Turkmenistan cut gas flow to Iran on January 1 due to a dispute over gas price and violation of take-or-pay term of the sides’ agreement.
Iran doubled gas import from Turkmenistan in 2015 to 9 bcm, but according to the agreement, it should have imported 14 bcm.
During a period from 2006 to 2016, Iran imported about 74.35 bcm of Turkmen gas, but based on the agreement, which was amended in 2007 and came into force in 2010, Iran should have imported 130 bcm of Turkmen gas.
8aea9bdd9ce302c6df436cf948299d04:
Iran is ready to start exporting natural gas to Iraq once Iraq makes the related payments.
Iran's Deputy Petroleum Minister Amir-Hossein Zamaniniya said that the pipeline connecting Iran and Iraq's gas networks has been filled with natural gas.
Iran and Iraq signed an agreement in 2013 for Iran to export 25 million cubic meters of gas per day to Iraq.
The project is estimated to earn Iran 3.7 billion U.S. dollars annually.
2365fc33f86c44edeeff769f3214a3be:
Iran's Oil Minister Bijan Namdar Zanganeh announced that Iran no longer needs gas from Turkmenistan.
Zanganeh stated that Iran has been importing Turkmen gas solely to promote political and economic relations with Turkmenistan.
Iran plans to increase domestic gas production by 200 million cubic meters starting in March 2023, potentially eliminating the need for Turkmen gas imports.
Iran was previously the second-largest customer for Turkmen gas after China, following a 2009 pipeline explosion that disrupted supplies to Russia.
Iran is exploring the possibility of supplying gas to Europe via the Nabucco pipeline project, which could make Turkmenistan a competitor for gas exports.
If Iran ceases imports, Turkmenistan will be left with only two customers for its gas: China and Russia.
328abb0c166d88e5b9afbd19a7d9544b:
Iran's gas pipeline to Iraq will be inaugurated on Jan. 23.
Gas export to Iraq will not start in the coming days because Iraqi side is not yet ready to receive gas.
Iran has injected gas to the pipeline and is ready to start exporting gas to Iraq.

A gas pipeline between Iran and Iraq will be unveiled on Tuesday, but exports to Iraq will remain at a standstill.
Iran is ready to inject gas into the export pipeline, but the Iraqi side is still unprepared to receive Iran’s natural gas.
Banking issues need to be fully resolved before Iranian gas can be supplied to Iraq.
The second part of the sixth national pipeline with a length of 600 km is still under construction.
The national gas pipeline network has the capacity to carry 110 million cubic metres per day and it will supply natural gas to Iraq and Syria.
NIGC and the Iraqi Ministry of Electricity and Power signed a gas contract in 2013 and in 2016 the scope of the deal was extended in order to increase the export volume and duration.

As such, in hot seasons 35 and in cold ones 25 million cubic metres of natural gas will be supplied to the Baghdad region, yielding an aggregate of 10 billion cubic metres per year.

According to the agreement, 35 and 25 million cubic metres of natural gas will be exported to the Iraqi region in hot and cold seasons, respectively.
Though nearly three years have passed since the signing of the gas contract between Iran and Iraq, gas exports have remained at a standstill as delays have mainly been caused by activities of the Islamic State terrorist group as well as Iraq’s failure to fulfil the financial claims of contractors.
5f00aa3efd4c5fd4bb3bbc241b43f6c2:
Iran will pay $1.9 billion in compensation to Turkey after the International Court of Arbitration ruled in Ankara’s favor in a dispute over pricing.

Several international companies have started negotiations to establish themselves in Iran's oil and gas projects after the nuclear-related western and international sanctions against Iran were lifted.
Iran is in possession of one of the world's largest oil and gas reserves.
a78d36e75e4860099a2cc5617a24ff62:
Iran is ready to negotiate gas talks with Turkmenistan, but Turkmenistan must first compensate for damages.
Turkmenistan halted gas flow to Iran on January 1, claiming Iran owes $1.8 billion for gas received in 2007-2008.

Iran may consider not pursuing a legal case against Turkmenistan for the time being.
Iran would only negotiate a new agreement with Turkmenistan.
dfbb8a8228c8c89edab4d3db457a8b98:
Lukoil, Russia’s No.2 oil producer, is in talks with the National Iranian Oil Company (NIOC) to develop the Abe Timur and Mansuri oilfields in Iran.
Lukoil has presented its technical proposals and is discussing feedback from NIOC.
Lukoil hopes to have a decision from the Iranian side during the first half of 2017.
Iran hopes its new Iran Petroleum Contract (IPC) will attract foreign investors and boost production.
Lukoil is also interested in opportunities in other Middle Eastern countries such as Kuwait, Oman, and Abu Dhabi.
Lukoil is developing West Qurna Phase Two oilfield in Iraq, which is currently producing 400,000 barrels per day.

debed3c15edd9bc069fd574ffc05cd3f:
Russia's Lukoil company hopes to reach an agreement with Iran to develop two oilfields in Iran.

Talks with the National Iranian Oil Company are underway about developing the Ab Teymour and Mansouri oilfields in western Iran.
Lukoil has done "significant amount of analysis as to how potentially develop the project," and presented its technical proposals and views to the Iranian side.
Lukoil would like to have some decision during the first half of 2017 from the Iranian side but there are no strict deadlines to this process.
The two sides would start negotiations on contractual terms if the development plans were accepted by the Iranian side.
3b639186cfa866c6c75f8127d469463e:
Iran has started construction of 12 oil and gas condensate refinery complexes.
Iran is expecting to sign oil refining contracts worth $8.6 billion with Asian companies in coming months.
Iran is planning to restore its oil and gas sectors after major sanctions were lifted following the nuclear deal between Iran and six world powers in July 2015.
Iran has a total capacity of 1.73 million barrels operating across Iran at present.
Iran is negotiating three separate oil refining contracts with China, Japan and South Korea.
Iran is expecting to sign a $2 billion contract with a South Korean company to boost oil processing capacity at the refinery in central province of Isafahan.
A $3 billion contract is expected to be signed this month with a Chinese company to develop and improve the quality of the refinery in Abadan city in western province of Khuzestan.

Iran also plans to sign contracts worth $14 billion to revive and upgrade the quality of five oil refineries in the country.
fbe52168e14ce9018a4df5c91cd892b6:
Iran has extended the deadline for bids on oil and gas projects to February 15.
Iran has urged British Petroleum (BP) to join major international companies that have already applied for the bidding round.
Iran has received bids from Anglo-Dutch giant Shell, Italy´s ENI, France´s Total, Russia´s Gazprom and Lukoil, and Schlumberger of the Netherlands.
Asian giants including China´s CNPC and Sinopec International, the Japanese Mitsubishi Corporation and Japan Petroleum Exploration also put in bids along with companies from Malaysia and South Korea.
Iran has increased production to 3.9 million barrels per day from 2.6 million bpd before President Hassan Rouhani took office in 2013.
Iran has earned more than $2 billion (1.9 billion euros) from gas sales since sanctions were lifted.
Iran has signed a flurry of deals with international companies, including a preliminary agreement with French oil and gas giant Total for a $4.8-billion (4.3-billion-euro) project to develop an offshore gas field at South Pars, which Iran shares with Qatar.
