Iran and Oman signed a document to renew an agreement to build a pipeline to export natural gas from Iran to Oman.
The agreement was signed by advisor to the Petroleum Minister and in charge of following up claims of the Ministry Ali Asghar Hendi and Director General for discovery and oil, gas production of Oil Ministry of Oman Ceif Hamad al-Salmani.
The meeting to renew the agreement was held in the presence of Petroleum Minister Bijan Zangeneh and Omani Minister of Oil and Gas Mohammad bin Hamad al-Rumhi.
Representatives from companies like French Total, Shell (Dutch-British), South Korean Cogs, German Uniper and Japanese Mitsui were present and offered their proposals for possible participation in the project.
Iran and Oman signed a Memorandum of Understanding in 2013 to export natural gas to Oman through a pipeline from under the Persian Gulf seabed.
The pipeline is expected to pass through deep waters of the Oman Sea due to opposition from the United Arab Emirates.
Iranian companies have construction and installation technology to build pipelines in shallow waters but lack experience in deep-water installations.
238d655f933e037f8ae9b67d2477544e:
The National Iranian Oil Company (NIOC) signed a memorandum of understanding with Malaysia's Bukhary International Ventures (BIV) to study two gas fields in Iran.
The Malaysian firm will undertake studies in Iran's Ferdowsi and Golshan gas fields and submit its feasibility studies to the NIOC within seven months.
The reserve at the Golshan gas field is estimated at more than 50 trillion cubic feet of gas and is expected to produce 2.5 billion cubic feet of natural gas per day.
The Ferdowsi gas reserve is estimated at around 10 trillion cubic feet and would produce more than 880 million cubic feet of gas on a daily basis.
The BIV will study gas extraction from the fields and its transfer to onshore to convert to LNG.
The fields also possess very heavy crude oil, which Iran has never extracted before.
The signed MoU follows a deal that was made in 2007 with Malaysia's Bukhary group.
40ea90965045eab6388aba3059699687:
President Trump's rhetoric as Commander in Chief may affect his personal culpability over potential crimes under international law.
Incitement may be enough to create criminal culpability, and President Trump is responsible for ensuring US military and operatives act consistent with US and international law.
President Trump has expressed his preference for torture and killing innocent family members of terror suspects.
For any conviction to occur, there would have to be a court willing to entertain investigation and prosecution, as well as sufficient evidence of the alleged crime.
National courts, including US courts, could enforce criminal and/or civil provisions of international law, particularly to the degree such have been adopted as part of such country's laws.
Sovereign immunity may preclude prosecution while in office, but other avenues may be suitable, such as civil and criminal liability, as Trump remains owner of a global business empire.
Judgments against Trump's business empire could be secured in national courts.
Violations of international humanitarian law as adopted in US law may be the basis for impeachment proceedings.
The US is not currently party to the International Criminal Court, but the ICC's codes and practice have been influenced by western democracies, particularly America's European allies.
The ICC was not intended to be a court of primary jurisdiction and continues to preside as a tribunal of complementary jurisdiction that would only act if national courts are unwilling or unable to intercede.
The ICC continues to further the standards and consensus on war crimes, the crime of aggression, and crimes against humanity.
The more realistic investigation and prosecution of Trump may come from national courts, within western democracies or the US.
Plaintiffs and prosecutors could seek remedy to Trump in ways generally not a realistic option before, as Trump has assets all around the globe.
Trump's rhetoric and actions, such as the "Mexico Wall" and "Muslim Ban," add to the body of evidence of discrimination and possible persecution.
Trump's alliance with Vladimir Putin, whose Kremlin has been linked to violations in Georgia, Ukraine, and Crimea, raises concerns about the US adopting similar tactics.
Trump's own words would reveal intent as well as action, where ambiguity or silence may have been a more clever precedent.
Impeachment may be a more likely consequence of possible violations as ever more developed international humanitarian law also becomes part of US standards.
Unlike previous US Commanders in Chief, President Trump could be hurt in an unprecedented manner, where perhaps he is most sensitive, in his personal wealth.
059da9dbc6b877f82ec14f60516ac934:
President Donald Trump announced his choice to fill the vacant Supreme Court seat on Tuesday.
Judge Neil Gorsuch was chosen to fill the vacant Supreme Court seat.
White House counsel Don McGahn informed the other finalists, Judges Thomas Hardiman, Judge William Pryor and Amul Thapar, that they would not be chosen.
President Trump personally called Judge Neil Gorsuch to invite him to Washington for the big announcement.
Judge Neil Gorsuch and his wife, Louise, were escorted to Washington with as much secrecy as possible, including traveling along "a back farm road" and boarding a military jet.
Judge Neil Gorsuch avoided staying at any hotels in Washington, instead laying low at the home of friends until it was time to head to the White House for the announcement.
White House staff prepared Judge Neil Gorsuch for the hefty job ahead and the uphill fight he'll face to get confirmed.
On Wednesday, Judge Neil Gorsuch will begin meetings with various groups and individuals, including members of the Senate Judiciary Committee.
d1833a926cb276ba202c4d17e527a83e:
Vice President Mike Pence defended President Trump's criticism of a federal judge who blocked an executive order temporarily barring immigrants and refugees from seven countries from entering the country.
Pence said that the president spoke his mind when calling the judge who blocked the immigration order a "so-called judge."
Pence said that the executive order was legal and appropriate and that the administration would be using all legal means at its disposal to challenge the judge's order.
3b3b83f6e5b0d072d901185f01e2f956:
National Security Advisor Michael Flynn's conversations with the Russian ambassador about lifting sanctions on Moscow before President Donald Trump took office have damaged his credibility and raised concerns about the Trump administration's relationship with Russia.
Flynn initially denied discussing sanctions, but later walked back his denials, saying he could not be certain the topic never came up.
The White House has not defended Flynn, and Vice President Mike Pence has admitted that his previous denial of sanctions talk was based on Flynn's own account.
Flynn could potentially face charges for violating the Logan Act, which bars private citizens from negotiating with foreign governments on issues affecting the U.S. government.
Democrats have demanded Flynn's resignation if the allegations are true, and have urged House and Senate intelligence committees to accelerate their investigations into potential ties between Trump's top aides and the Russian government.
Republicans initially refused to expand the scope of the investigation to Trump's aides, but later agreed to do so after Democrats threatened to boycott.
Flynn is reportedly under investigation as part of ongoing inquiries into the Trump team's contacts and ties to Russia.
The revelations about Flynn have fueled concerns in Congress and among career diplomats and intelligence officers about the Trump administration's overtures to Russia without clear demands for concessions in return.
Some experts predict the Trump White House will strike a deal with Russia to lift sanctions in exchange for Russian assistance in the fight against the Islamic State.
Six Republicans and six Democrats have proposed a bill to require a review of any measure to lift sanctions on Russia.
787a9e519448b65aa3f267d71cfbf7cb:
National Security Advisor Michael Flynn's political future is in doubt after the White House announced President Donald Trump is "evaluating" his contacts with the Russian government.
Flynn is accused of discussing the Obama administration's election-hacking-related sanctions with Russian Ambassador Sergey Kislyak, which he initially denied.
Flynn has since apologized to Vice President Mike Pence, who had publicly defended him.
The White House said Trump is speaking to Pence and "various other people" about the situation, which could spell the beginning of the end for Flynn.
Flynn has been an instrumental player in Trump's inner circle and encouraged tougher policies on Iran and a softer policy on Russia.
Several Democratic lawmakers have called on Flynn to resign over the situation, which has become a major embarrassment for the ruling Republicans.
The Justice Department and Congress are both investigating possible links between Trump campaign advisors and Moscow.
9918131c5e92c81f3340d6272c8e5be3:
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu met with President Donald Trump on Wednesday.
The meeting was overshadowed by the resignation of Trump's National Security Adviser Michael Flynn.
Flynn resigned over his connections to the Russian government and conversations with the Russian Ambassador in Washington.
Flynn was a central figure in setting up the meeting between Trump and Netanyahu.
Mossad Director Yossi Cohen and acting national security adviser Jacob Nagel met twice with Flynn since Trump's election victory.
It remains unclear how Flynn's resignation will affect the meeting between Trump and Netanyahu.
President Trump appointed General Keith Kellogg as acting national security adviser.
Netanyahu is quite angry over leaks from Sunday's security-cabinet meeting.
Netanyahu's chief of staff said he is not ruling out an investigation of the leaks, including polygraph tests of the ministers present.
01879277c09553f6b51d352d4815792e:
Michael Flynn resigned as Donald Trump's national security adviser amid controversy over his contacts with the Russian government.
Flynn admitted to "inadvertently briefing" Vice President Mike Pence with "incomplete information" about his calls with Russian ambassador Sergey Kislyak.
Flynn's resignation comes after details of his calls with Kislyak were made public, increasing pressure on Trump to take action.
Several US media outlets reported that top Trump advisers were warned about Flynn's contacts with the Russians early this year.
The Justice Department had warned the White House that Flynn had misled senior administration officials about the contents of his talks with Kislyak, making him vulnerable to Russian blackmail.
Flynn's resignation will fuel calls for an independent investigation into Russia's influence during the 2016 US presidential election.
Flynn had been an instrumental player in Trump's inner circle and was an early supporter of Trump's bid for the presidency.
Flynn's resignation took place just days before his first official talks with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.
720e6fcf7ee707e59a9844c89dbe407b:
Donald Trump's presidency faced a crisis after National Security Advisor Mike Flynn resigned due to his dealings with Russia.
Flynn admitted to misleading Vice President Mike Pence about his call with Russian ambassador Sergey Kislyak.
Democrats demanded an independent investigation into alleged collusion between Trump's inner circle and Russia.
The CIA, FBI, and other intelligence agencies have investigated Moscow's influence on the 2016 election.
Republicans in Congress are divided on whether to investigate Flynn's behavior further.
The Justice Department warned the White House that Flynn's contacts with Russia could make him vulnerable to blackmail.
White House spokesman Sean Spicer denied that Trump knew about Flynn's discussions with Russia.
Flynn was an early supporter of Trump and advocated for tougher policies on Iran and a softer policy on Russia.
Trump named retired lieutenant general Keith Kellogg as interim national security advisor.
Potential permanent replacements for Flynn include retired general David Petraeus and former vice admiral Robert Harward.
5b9cb27ea5126aa2ff66a1d6306bf3a5:
Michael Flynn resigned as US National Security Advisor.
Flynn's resignation is seen as a sign of weakness in the new US Administration.
Flynn's resignation is the result of internal conflicts within the new US Administration.
The 1799 Logan Act was used to drive a wedge between the United States and Russia and complicate the work of the new US Administration.
Flynn's resignation is a victory for the Democrats and the US mainstream media.
The US political journalism website Washington Free Beacon reported that members of the former US Administration allegedly conducted "a secret, months-long campaign" to discredit Michael Flynn.
03ae0cb58c485bcd1a381300e66963fc:
Former Obama administration confidantes secretly campaigned for months to handicap President Donald Trump’s national security apparatus and preserve the nuclear deal with Iran.
The effort included a small task force of Obama loyalists who deluged media outlets with stories aimed at eroding Flynn’s credibility.
The operation primarily focused on discrediting Flynn, an opponent of the Iran nuclear deal, in order to handicap the Trump administration’s efforts to disclose secret details of the nuclear deal with Iran that had been long hidden by the Obama administration.
Obama loyalists plotted in the months before Trump’s inauguration to establish a set of roadblocks before Trump’s national security team, which includes several prominent opponents of diplomacy with Iran.
Flynn had been preparing to publicize many of the details about the nuclear deal that had been intentionally hidden by the Obama administration as part of its effort to garner support for the deal.
Sources in and out of the White House are concerned that the campaign against Flynn will be extended to other prominent figures in the Trump administration.
The larger issue that should trouble the American people is the far-reaching power of unknown, unelected apparatchiks in the Intelligence Community deciding for themselves both who serves in government and what is an acceptable policy they will allow the elected representatives of the people to pursue.
Michael Flynn was one of the Obama administration’s fiercest critics after he was forced out of the Defense Intelligence Agency.
Flynn was a withering critic of Obama’s biggest foreign policy initiative, the Iran deal.
The Obama administration knew that Flynn was going to release the secret documents around the Iran deal, which would blow up their myth that it was a good deal that rolled back Iran.
be6e9d5da670504258411c2b044d3fca:
The Democratic Party tries to create preconditions for US President Donald Trump's impeachment by bringing more and more accusations against his team.
The New York Times reported that some of Trump's associates allegedly had contacts with Russian intelligence officials, citing four current and former American officials.
One of Trump's advisors allegedly spotted communicating with Russian security agents was Paul Manafort.
Paul Manafort dismissed the allegations as "absurd."
0c1bfeda35e63185cb0549452fe80c29:
Former Director of National Intelligence James Clapper says President Trump must exercise caution while investigating leaks from within his administration.
Trump pledged to punish people who leaked damaging information about his administration’s inner workings to the press.
The New York Times reported Wednesday that Trump plans to appoint Stephen A. Feinberg to conduct a “review” of intelligence agencies after leaks rattled the administration.
Trump criticized the intelligence community Wednesday for leaks that led him to oust former national security adviser Michael Flynn.
Flynn resigned Monday amid reports he misled senior White House officials about his phone calls with Russia’s ambassador in December.
Reports emerged last week that, despite denials, Flynn and Kislyak discussed U.S. sanctions against Russia before Trump entered office.
Reports Tuesday said several aides and allies to Trump’s 2016 presidential campaign were in repeated contact with senior Russian intelligence officers.
Current and former U.S. officials reportedly found no evidence of collusion in regards to last year’s presidential race or the hacking of Democratic organizations beforehand.
41179137bd8055e10c7231aef761b0f7:
Rep. Earl Blumenauer of Oregon plans to form a working group to clarify and strengthen the 25th Amendment of the U.S. Constitution.
Blumenauer's effort is in response to Republican Donald Trump's presidency, even though there have been no signs of an effort to remove him.
Blumenauer believes there is a flaw in the 25th Amendment that allows the president to fire the Cabinet, undermining the check on an unstable president.
Blumenauer suggests that living former presidents and vice presidents could form the "some other body" that could begin the process of removing the president from office.
It's unclear if anyone else has signed on to Blumenauer's effort.
Republican Vice President Mike Pence is in line to succeed Trump.
8ea7c15535399535aa446c8742df4960:
Republican lawmakers are pushing for an investigation into the Trump administration’s ties to Russia.
The Kremlin says political turbulence in the United States is delaying the resumption of better relations between Washington and Moscow.
President Trump is preparing a handful of executive orders to reshape the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency.
President Trump dropped a U.S. commitment to a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said the European Union and Canada needed to lead the international economy in challenging times.
More than 20 million people may die from starvation due to four separate famines over the next six months.
Malaysian police detained a third suspect in connection with the murder of Kim Jong Nam, the half-brother of North Korean leader Kim Jong Un.
Republican U.S. Senator Susan Collins of Maine said she would oppose Oklahoma Attorney General Scott Pruitt's nomination to head the Environmental Protection Agency.
America's largest banks are to propose a complete overhaul of how financial institutions investigate and report potential criminal activity.
Austria filed a lawsuit against Airbus and the Eurofighter consortium, alleging them of willful deception and fraud linked to a 2 billion euro ($2.1 billion) order for Eurofighter jets in 2003.
Snap Inc, the owner of the popular messaging app Snapchat, set a valuation of between $16.20 billion and $18.52 billion in its initial public offering, significantly below expectations.
db4d0becfee9cb4355a473101e9e8a5b:
Senate Republicans have not heard of allegations that President Trump's national security adviser Mike Flynn was targeted for leaks due to his hostility to the Iran deal.
Reports that Flynn resigned due to leaks orchestrated by former Obama officials to protect undisclosed side deals of the Iran deal received broad attention.
Senate Foreign Relations chairman Bob Corker, Senate Armed Services chairman John McCain, and Sen. Lindsey Graham have not heard of the claim.
Former deputy national security adviser Ben Rhodes denied involvement in the leaks.
Sen. Lindsey Graham doubts that Flynn is a casualty in a political proxy war over the Iran deal.
Sen. Lindsey Graham condemned the flood of leaks as an unprecedented attack on a president.
Corker suggested that a "fulsome investigation" of Russian interference in the presidential election might stem the tide of leaks.
0f86b49bfda260851718c833c5dd5849:
White House chief of staff Reince Priebus asked a top FBI official to help dispute media reports about Trump campaign advisers' contacts with Russian intelligence agents.
The FBI had not publicly stated that the New York Times report describing Trump advisers’ contacts with Russia was not accurate.
Priebus’ discussion with the FBI’s deputy director sparked outrage among some Democrats, who said he was violating policies intended to limit communications between the law enforcement agency and the White House on pending investigations.
The White House official was not authorized to disclose the matter publicly and insisted on anonymity.
72094b8e60d78d1d8e3e3996f673d6e9:
President Trump has repeatedly accused the media of being biased against him, and the friction between the Trump administration and the Washington press corps has escalated.
The Trump administration has excluded certain news outlets, including CNN, from press conferences.
The Trump administration has portrayed the media as enemies of the administration and the people.
The media has a choice to continue to try to do its job fairly and objectively or to accept the Trump administration's premise that the media and the administration are enemies.
Jake Tapper, a leading CNN anchor, tweeted to Sean Spicer, the press secretary for the Trump administration, accusing him of being annoyed by false information about his birthplace, and copied the tweet to former-President Barack Obama's Twitter account.
Tapper's tweet was seen as an attempt to embarrass and insult the Trump administration.
CNN's response to Trump's accusations of unfairness has been to have one of its most recognizable on-camera figures troll a senior administration figure.
c8f3a397bb2551aa8af6f093d649bcc7:
Acting Deputy Attorney General Dana Boente will take over all investigations into Russia's potential meddling in the 2016 election.
Attorney General Jeff Sessions has recused himself from those matters.
Boente was appointed to be acting deputy attorney general in late January after President Trump fired Sally Yates.
Boente is acting deputy attorney general until the president's nominee, Rod Rosenstein is confirmed.
Boente was nominated by former President Barack Obama for his role in the Eastern District of Virginia and has worked for the DOJ for more than three decades.
The Eastern District of Virginia is considered a very high-profile district, as it is home to the CIA and the Pentagon.
Former AG Loretta Lynch called Boente one of the department's "consummate utility players" who notably led the corruption prosecutions of former Virginia Gov. Bob McDonnell, former Louisiana Rep. William J. Jefferson and former New Orleans mayor Ray Nagin.
d644b253f3c71b3a676e00c76cd68be4:
Sen. Claire McCaskill (D-Mo.) called for Attorney General Jeff Sessions' resignation after The Washington Post revealed that he'd met with Sergey Kislyak, Russia's ambassador to the United States, twice during the presidential campaign.
McCaskill stated that she hadn't had a meeting with the Russian ambassador herself in a decade.
McCaskill's statement appears to be false, based on her own tweets in 2013 and 2015, which show that she attended meetings with Kislyak.
McCaskill later acknowledged that she had indeed gone to a meeting about international adoptions that Kislyak also attended, but told reporters that multiple senators were there and she did not participate in a one-on-one meeting with him.
U.S. intelligence agencies have concluded that Russia interfered in the U.S. election with the goal of helping Donald Trump.
Several lawmakers have called for Sessions to step aside and appoint an independent investigator to probe Trump's ties to Russia.
4a979c893b83f26c0ef4c25116b339d7:
Several senators on both sides of the aisle backed Attorney General Jeff Sessions after he sought to blunt resignation calls from senior Democrats.
Sessions met with Russia's ambassador last year, a detail omitted from recent congressional testimony.
Sessions' defenders say such meetings between senators and diplomats were routine.
Democratic Missouri Sen. Claire McCaskill initially claimed she never called or met with Russia's ambassador, but tweets surfaced indicating she had, at least twice.
Other former colleagues intentionally came to Sessions' defense, backing the former Alabama senator's claim he only met with Russian Ambassador Sergey Kislyak in his official capacity as a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee.
Sen. Joe Manchin, D-W.Va., said he met with the Russian ambassador with a group of other senators in his official capacity.
Sen. Roy Blunt, R-Mo., said he had talked to at least twenty ambassadors in the last six weeks.
Sen. Ted Cruz, R-Texas, said he would meet with Russian Ambassador Sergey Kislyak without reservations.
The statements of support came as other lawmakers, including the two top-ranking Democrats, Rep. Nancy Pelosi and Sen. Chuck Schumer, demanded Sessions' resignation.
Sessions is maintaining he never discussed campaign matters with the Russian ambassador, and the White House has backed him.
Sessions met often with ambassadors from a variety of countries, including four with the ambassador for Great Britain.
McCaskill tweeted she had never met with the Russian ambassador, but tweets surfaced indicating she had, at least twice.
61fd36851482fcf5fff0e61c36077747:
President Donald Trump’s Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin told his new aides he would not tolerate leaks to the news media.
Access to a classified computer system at the White House has been tightened by political appointees to prevent professional staffers from seeing memos being prepared for the new president.
Some officials at the Department of Homeland Security fear a witch hunt is under way for the leaker of a draft intelligence report which found little evidence that citizens of seven Muslim-majority countries covered by Trump’s now-suspended travel ban pose a threat to the United States.
Washington career civil servants say the clampdown appears designed to try to limit the flow of information inside and outside government and deter officials from talking to the media about topics that could result in negative stories.
Trump has described media outlets as “lying”, “corrupt”, “failing” and “the enemy of the American people.”
Trump asked the Department of Justice to look into leaks of “classified information that was given illegally” to journalists regarding the relationship between his aides and Russia.
Several officials in different agencies fear their phone calls and emails may be monitored and are reluctant to speak their minds during internal discussions.
Limits imposed on the flow of information have blindsided cabinet-level officials on some major issues and led to uncertainty among foreign governments about U.S. policy.
White House spokesman Sean Spicer demanded that some aides surrender their phones so they could be checked for calls or texts to reporters.
During Republican Richard Nixon’s administration, the FBI wiretapped White House aides and journalists.
Trump’s predecessor, Democrat Barack Obama, aggressively pursued leaks to try to “control the narrative,” as White House aides put it.
New York Times reporter James Risen said the Obama administration prosecuted nine cases involving whistleblowers and leakers, compared with three by all previous administrations combined.
At the State Department, the fear of getting caught in a leak investigation or running afoul of White House positions is so acute that some officials will discuss issues only face-to-face rather than use phones, email, texts or other messaging applications.
There is high anxiety in parts of DHS, officials there said.
Officials fear phone calls and emails are being monitored to try to find who leaked the draft intelligence report to the Associated Press.
Before Trump’s Jan. 20 inauguration, National Security Council officials drafting memos, or “packages,” for the president on a classified computer system could choose other officials who should have input.
Under a change made after Trump took office, staffers cannot choose who may see and edit a memo. Instead, access is approved by the office of the NSC executive secretary, retired Army lieutenant general Keith Kellogg.
The policy change suggested the White House wants to tighten control over internal deliberations.
a769198b312bcbe9f40f735bbec237bd:
Jared Kushner, Donald Trump's son-in-law and senior advisor, attended a controversial meeting in December between a Russian diplomat and former national security advisor Michael Flynn.
The meeting between Kushner, Flynn and Russian Ambassador Sergey Kislyak lasted 20 minutes at Trump Tower and was intended to “establish a line of communication.”
The FBI is currently investigating alleged Russian involvement in November’s U.S. election.
Kushner was not known to have participated in talks with Russian officials prior to the report.
Attorney General Jeff Sessions said he would recuse himself from the FBI investigation into Trump campaign links to Russia.
Sessions admitted he had discussed Ukraine with Kislyak at the Republican National Convention, which he used Trump campaign money to attend.
Trump said that Kushner would take on the task of negotiating peace between Israelis and Palestinians.
9fb4d3311dc0318e8811f6479828aea1:
Attorney General Jeff Sessions will recuse himself from any investigations related to Russian interference in the 2016 election.
Sessions denies meeting with Russian operatives or intermediaries about the Trump campaign and denies being part of a "continuing exchange of information" between Trump surrogates and Russian government intermediaries.
Sessions met with the Russian ambassador twice as a senator on the Senate Armed Services Committee, which was not out of the ordinary.
Sessions did not disclose the meetings with the Russian ambassador during his confirmation hearings because he was responding to a different question about communications with the Trump campaign.
Democrats are accusing Sessions of perjury for not disclosing the meetings with the Russian ambassador, but Republicans say it was not unusual for him to meet with foreign ambassadors as a senator.
House Intelligence Committee chairman Rep. Devin Nunes says there is no evidence that the Trump campaign colluded with Russia.
Speaker of the House Paul Ryan says there is zero evidence that the Trump campaign ever coordinated with Russia.
James Clapper, President Obama's own director of national intelligence, said Russian interference did not impact vote tallies.
b49c43adf10444c10d9f5fbda96f3ecb:
Sen. Rand Paul (R-Ky.) urged lawmakers to move past controversy surrounding Attorney General Jeff Sessions’s contacts with Russia’s ambassador to the U.S.
Paul said the biggest debate in the Capitol and in the country right now is what to do with healthcare.
Paul defended the Trump administration last month, pushing back on calls for a congressional investigation following the ouster of Trump’s first national security adviser, Michael Flynn.
Sessions faced intense pressure to recuse himself after The Washington Post reported Wednesday that the former Trump surrogate twice spoke with Russian Ambassador Sergey Kislyak during the campaign.
Paul appeared to wave off the attorney general’s meeting with Kislyak during the Republican National Convention last summer, pointing out that Democratic Sen. Claire McCaskill (Mo.) had also previously met with the Russian ambassador.
A spokesperson for McCaskill said Thursday that in 2013 the McCaskill “did attend a group meeting about adoptions with other Senators, and had a brief proactive call with the ambassador amid calls to several other parties to the Iran nuclear deal.”
17b4f74f9b19c4cc163bf9a536a953e9:
Attorney General Jeff Sessions has recused himself from any Justice Department investigation of alleged Russian election interference.
Acting Deputy Attorney General Dana Boente will oversee any investigations related to the presidential campaigns by the FBI or Justice Department attorneys.
The White House has nominated U.S. attorney in Baltimore, Rod Rosenstein, to the position of Deputy Attorney General.
Sessions could potentially step back into any investigation if an allegation surfaces about anything that may have happened after Election Day.
Senate Democratic leader Chuck Schumer urged Boente to appoint an independent special counsel to oversee any inquiries.
Sessions made it clear that he believes special counsels should be appointed to avoid even the appearance of a conflict of interest.
719d7438da424f4080a65bde7e0b6b9e:
Rod Rosenstein, the longest-serving U.S. attorney, is set to lead the probe into Trump’s Russia connections and Russia’s possible involvement in his campaign.
Rosenstein is probably the least partisan figure Trump has appointed for any position.
Rosenstein has won praise from colleagues and from the press for his job as Maryland’s U.S. attorney, one in which he did not seem to allow politics to paint his prosecutorial decisions.
Rosenstein’s confirmation hearing is set for Tuesday and is now expected to focus on his ability to conduct an independent investigation into Russia’s involvement in the elections.
9f358287a500a322f916c02eae67dc3e:
Rod Rosenstein, the longest-serving US attorney, is being tapped to oversee the FBI's investigation into Russian meddling and any links between Russian officials and Trump's associates.
Rosenstein is widely respected by Democrats and Republicans for his experience working on sensitive cases in the face of political pressure.
Rosenstein successfully prosecuted then-Prince George's County (Maryland) executive Jack Johnson for corruption.
Rosenstein announced indictments against seven Baltimore police officers in a racketeering conspiracy.
Rosenstein is credited with turning around a troubled US attorney's office.
Rosenstein was tapped by former attorney-general Eric Holder Jr to oversee the investigations into the leaking of classified national security information.
Rosenstein is expected to be responsible for the day-to-day running of the sprawling Justice Department, which has 113,000 employees across the country.
Rosenstein will also take on the oversight of all federal investigations into Russia and the 2016 presidential election.
69ecd76a446bee56199cc34c79eca20e:
Donald Trump's tweets on Saturday accused Barack Obama of wiretapping phones at his campaign headquarters at Trump Tower in Manhattan in October.
Trump's tweets also claimed that a "lower court" failed to approve a request for wiretapping his headquarters, which means that a higher court did.
The FBI, after being duly authorized by the Justice Department, succeeded in convincing a special tribunal set up in accordance with the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act that despite the danger of being accused of improper interference in the political process, there was enough “probable cause” to suspect that Trump and/or his underlings were in contact with a foreign entity or foreign intelligence service.
If the FBI did wiretap Trump's headquarters, Trump himself may have offered the noose from which he might ultimately hang, politically speaking.
Democrats will be particularly incensed to learn that while FBI Director James Comey was concealing the possibility that the GOP presidential candidate might be guilty of treason, he found it necessary to publicize an extremely damaging letter about Hillary Clinton’s emails just nine days before the elections.
The new mayhem will undoubtedly expand polarization in Washington as many Republicans jump to Trump’s defense.
It takes only a few Republicans who haven’t lost their conscience to turn the demand for an independent investigation of Russiagate affair into an ultimatum that can’t be refused.
ff376b0ec3846e495e25ea5747bfb706:
Former Director of National Intelligence James Clapper denied President Donald Trump’s accusation that former President Barack Obama wiretapped him.
The New York Times reported that FBI Director James Comey asked the Justice Department to reject Trump’s wiretapping claim because it was false, but the department had not done so.
The White House urged Congress to investigate Trump’s allegation as part of an ongoing congressional probe into Russia’s influence on the 2016 U.S. presidential campaign.
Democrats accused Trump of trying to distract from the rising controversy about possible ties to Russia.
White House spokesman Sean Spicer said Trump and administration officials would have no further comment on the issue until Congress has completed its probe.
U.S. Representative Devin Nunes, Republican head of the House of Representatives Intelligence Committee, said any possible surveillance on campaign officials would be part of the probe.
Trump made the wiretapping accusation in a series of early morning tweets on Saturday amid expanding scrutiny of his campaign’s ties to Russia.
An Obama spokesman denied the charge, saying it was “a cardinal rule” that no White House official interfered with independent Justice Department investigations.
Senate Democratic leader Chuck Schumer said Trump had either made a false accusation or a judge had found probable cause to authorize a wiretap.
Clapper said “there was no evidence” of collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia in a January intelligence report concluding Russian interference in the 2016 election.
Trump should immediately turn over any evidence he has to support his allegation, said U.S. Senator Susan Collins, a Maine Republican who serves on the Senate Intelligence Committee.
Trump fired his first national security adviser, Michael Flynn, in February after revelations that he had discussed U.S. sanctions on Russia with the Russian ambassador before Trump took office.
Josh Earnest, the White House press secretary under Obama, said the president did not have the authority to unilaterally order a wiretap of a U.S. citizen.
2387d2adc4363db0c0f86089e6a4d547:
White House Spokesman Sean Spicer said U.S. President Donald Trump has almost certainly not spoken to FBI Director James Comey about Trump's claim that the previous administration wiretapped him during the 2016 election campaign.
FBI Director James Comey has asked the Justice Department to reject Trump's accusation that former President Barack Obama ordered a wiretap at Trump Tower in New York because the claim was false and must be corrected.
Trump gave no evidence for his claim, the latest twist in a controversy over ties between Trump associates and Russia that has dogged the early days of his presidency.
The wiretapping allegation hit U.S. stocks on Monday.
Democrats accused Trump of making the wiretapping claim to try to distract from controversy about possible links to Russia.
A Republican lawmaker who heads a House of Representatives oversight panel said on Monday he had seen no direct evidence to back Trump's wiretapping assertion.
The White House asked the Republican-controlled Congress to examine, as part of an ongoing congressional probe into Russia's influence on the election, whether the Obama administration abused its investigative authority.
106b8dd31f385e0b5cb9f0eabfa35036:
Rod Rosenstein, President Donald Trump's nominee to be the second-ranking official in the Department of Justice, faced a Senate Judiciary Committee hearing on Tuesday.
Rosenstein would lead the DOJ's daily operations and oversee probes into ties between Trump's inner circle and Russia if confirmed as deputy attorney general.
Rosenstein is a longtime prosecutor who served under Republican and Democratic presidents, George W. Bush and Barack Obama.
Rosenstein has bipartisan support, including from both of his state's Democratic senators.
The hearing was heated at times, as senators focused intently on questions about Russia and Trump's assertion of wiretapping.
Rosenstein is "as apolitical a career prosecutor as it gets at senior level," says Benjamin Wittes, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution and editor-in-chief of the Lawfare blog.
Many of the committee members agree that Rosenstein deserves the chance to work inside the DOJ and learn about whatever investigation is taking place before being asked to make a final decision on whether a special counsel should be appointed.
Politico/Morning Consult polling this month showed a majority—56 percent—of registered voters support appointing a special prosecutor to investigate any ties between Trump's campaign staff and the Russian government.
621e3580eb1086aa39a559ac88e9bd01:
White House press secretary Sean Spicer said President Donald Trump was not aware that his former national security adviser, Michael Flynn, had worked to further the interests of the government of Turkey before appointing him.
Flynn and his firm, Flynn Intel Group Inc., filed paperwork with the Justice Department formally identifying himself as a foreign agent and acknowledging that his work for a company owned by a Turkish businessman could have aided Turkey’s government.
Flynn and his company filed the registration paperwork describing $530,000 worth of lobbying before Election Day for Inovo BV, a Dutch-based company owned by Turkish businessman Ekim Alptekin.
Flynn’s disclosure that his lobbying may have benefited Turkey’s authoritarian government led by President Recep Tayyip Erdogan comes as Flynn has drawn scrutiny from the FBI for his contacts with Russian officials.
Flynn and his firm acknowledged that lobbying from August through November “could be construed to have principally benefited the Republic of Turkey.”
After Flynn joined the Trump administration, he agreed not to lobby for five years after leaving government service and never to represent foreign governments.
Under the Foreign Agent Registration Act, U.S. citizens who lobby on behalf of foreign governments or political entities must disclose their work to the Justice Department.
Alptekin said in a phone call from Istanbul that the changes were a response to “political pressure” and he did not agree with Flynn’s decision to file the registration documents with the Justice Department.
Trump fired Flynn last month for misleading Vice President Mike Pence and other administration officials about his contacts with Russia’s ambassador to the U.S., Sergey Kislyak.
61f340c327f41f10bb76a2db867f910e:
The White House has softened President Donald Trump’s unproven assertion that his predecessor wiretapped his New York skyscraper during the election.
White House spokesman Sean Spicer said the president wasn’t using the word wiretapping literally, noting that Trump had put the term in quotation marks.
Spicer suggested Trump wasn’t accusing former President Barack Obama specifically, but instead referring to the actions of the Obama administration.
The Justice Department faces a deadline to provide lawmakers evidence to back up Trump’s explosive claim.
The FBI is investigating Trump associates’ contacts with Russia during the election, as are House and Senate intelligence committees.
The House committee has turned the matter back on the Trump administration, setting a Monday deadline for the Justice Department to provide evidence.
Sens. Lindsey Graham, R-S.C., and Sheldon Whitehouse, D-R.I., asked Acting Deputy Attorney General Dana Boente and FBI Director James Comey to produce the paper trail created when the Justice Department’s criminal division secures warrants for wiretaps.
Sen. John McCain, an influential Republican, said Sunday: “I think the president has one of two choices: either retract or to provide the information that the American people deserve.”
James Clapper, who was Obama’s director of national intelligence, has said that nothing matching Trump’s claims had taken place.
White House counselor Kellyanne Conway sidestepped questions about the lack of proof Monday, saying she was “not in the job of having evidence.”
4ecab1aa6b5e7f45b38384e2faa8269e:
FBI Director James Comey confirmed that the FBI is investigating possible links and coordination between Russia and associates of President Donald Trump as part of a broader probe of Russian interference in last year’s presidential election.
The FBI does not ordinarily discuss ongoing investigations, but Comey said he’d been authorized to do so given the extreme public interest in this case.
Comey publicly contradicted a series of tweets from Trump that declared the Republican candidate’s phones had been ordered tapped by President Barack Obama during the campaign.
Rep. Devin Nunes, a California Republican and chairman of the House intelligence committee, also rejected Trump’s claims that Obama had wiretapped his New York skyscraper during the campaign.
National Security Agency Director Michael Rogers also disputed allegations that surfaced last year that British intelligence services were involved in the wiretapping.
The top two lawmakers on the committee said Sunday that documents the Justice Department and FBI delivered late last week offered no evidence that the Obama administration had wiretapped Trump Tower, the president’s New York City headquarters.
The panel’s ranking Democrat said the material offered circumstantial evidence that American citizens colluded with Russians in Moscow’s efforts to interfere in the presidential election.
The Senate Intelligence Committee has scheduled a similar hearing for later in the month.
ce8696991980ef769a6d6092776bfdb5:
FBI Director James Comey confirmed that the investigation into potential ties between Trump's campaign and Russia is ongoing.
FBI Director James Comey and Adm. Michael Rogers denied Trump's claim that he was wiretapped by former President Barack Obama during the campaign.
The British GCHQ intelligence agency called the White House press secretary Sean Spicer's claim of British involvement in the wiretapping "utterly ridiculous."
Secretary of State Rex Tillerson will skip a key NATO summit in Brussels to meet with Chinese President Xi Jinping and Russian officials.
The Trump administration is considering new sanctions against North Korea to cut it off from the global financial system.
The FBI is investigating a network of bots linked to Russia that flooded social media with pro-Trump stories during the 2016 presidential campaign.
Russia has embedded ground troops with the Kurdish People's Protection Units (YPG) in Syria.
The U.S. is banning passengers traveling from airports in 10 predominately Muslim countries from carrying electronic devices larger than a cell phone in their carry-on luggage.
Syria is asking Russia to intervene and halt Israeli airstrikes on the country.
President Donald Trump's daughter Ivanka is getting a security clearance, a government-issued phone, and an office in the White House.
The head of the U.N.'s International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) says that North Korea has doubled the size of its uranium enrichment facility in Yongbyon.
934774f1c5dc7f95d491033cb0b2be38:
Paul Manafort, former campaign chairman for President Donald Trump, secretly worked for a Russian billionaire to advance the interests of Russian President Vladimir Putin a decade ago.
Manafort pitched a plan to the Kremlin around 2005 to influence politics, business dealings, and news coverage in the United States, Europe, and the former Soviet republics to benefit the Putin government.
Jared Kushner, President Donald Trump’s son-in-law and principal Middle East advisor, tried but failed to get Britain to scuttle a U.N. resolution denouncing Israeli settlements even before Trump took office.
Secretary of State Rex Tillerson said that he did not want or seek his job, but his wife convinced him that “God’s not through with you.”
Tillerson is back from his swing through Asia and will host the 68 members of the anti-Islamic State alliance Wednesday and Thursday at the State Department.
North Korea has, yet again, tested another missile, firing it off from the country’s east coast on Tuesday evening.
North Korea’s deputy ambassador at its U.N. Mission in Geneva tells Reuters that Pyongyang is rushing to build a “pre-emptive first strike capability” and an inter-continental ballistic missile.
Investigations of Russian casualties in Syria by Reuters and the Conflict Intelligence Team investigative group finds that Moscow has suffered more than three times more casualties than it has admitted to in public.
The U.S. Air Force is a big proponent of upgrading the U.S. nuclear arsenal.
Twitter has been busy suspending terrorism-related accounts, killing around 376,000 of them in the latter half of 2016.
Israel is girding for the possibility that war with either or Hamas or Hezbollah may be on the horizon, drawing up plans for its communities near the borders with Gaza and Lebanon to practice evacuating to safer areas.
96a37b2d0d3b22eeb53408a0d4fc19af:
Paul Manafort worked secretly in 2005 to advance Putin’s interests and undermine anti-Russian movements in the former Soviet republics.
Manafort tried to win a U.S. visa for Russian oligarch Oleg Deripaska, a close ally of Russian President Vladimir Putin.
The FBI and congressional committees investigate possible ties between the Trump campaign and Russian operatives, as well as Russian efforts to influence the 2016 presidential election.
FBI Director James Comey testified the FBI began investigating the Trump campaign in late July, while Manafort was still running Donald Trump’s presidential campaign.
Manafort signed a $10 million annual contract in 2006 with Deripaska, and the two retained business contacts until at least 2009.
Manafort and Deripaska had a falling out in 2014 over a $19 million investment in Ukrainian TV.
White House spokesman Sean Spicer said the president was unaware of Manafort’s relationship with Deripaska.
Manafort played a role in Philippine dictator Ferdinand Marcos 1986 election, which was rife with voter fraud.
Manafort helped Viktor Yanukovich win the Ukrainian presidency in 2010.
Manafort is the focus of a broad investigation into stolen Ukrainian assets taken when Yanukovich was ousted in 2014.
cf9480e92360e600e4a6419a9c059fb1:
House Intelligence Committee Chairman Devin Nunes announced that former Trump campaign adviser Paul Manafort has volunteered to testify before the committee about Russia's influence in the 2016 election.
Nunes has asked FBI Director James Comey and National Security Agency Director Mike Rogers to testify behind closed doors about the committee's ongoing investigation.
Nunes postponed the original open hearing that was scheduled for next Tuesday to allow for the closed-door testimony.
Ranking Democrat on the committee Adam Schiff opposed the idea of postponing the already scheduled meeting.
Nunes and Schiff have agreed to ask the FBI to brief the full committee about the ongoing counterintelligence investigation.
cbe4fc997fe19f0dbe72b89da320b84c:
The Senate Intelligence Committee is seeking to interview Jared Kushner, President Donald Trump’s son-in-law, as part of its investigation into ties between Trump associates and Russian officials.
Kushner would be the closest person to the president to be questioned in the congressional investigations into Russia’s role in the 2016 election.
Kushner has volunteered to speak to the Senate Intelligence Committee but has not received confirmation.
The Senate panel wants to ask Kushner about two meetings arranged with Russian Ambassador Sergei Kislyak at Trump Tower in New York in December, as well as a meeting with the head of Russia’s state-owned development bank.
The U.S. intelligence community has concluded Moscow orchestrated the hacking of Democratic Party groups during the campaign and released the stolen information to benefit Trump.
6835fd63939ae21ef5a2e4c673e96ae7:
A police probe into the deadly shooting of a Bedouin man in Umm al-Hiran revealed a breakdown in operational procedures.
The operation to evacuate and demolish homes in Umm al-Hiran was planned in just one afternoon, despite usually requiring weeks of planning.

Yemen's war has killed around 7,700 people and wounded 42,500 others since a Saudi-led Arab coalition intervened in support of the government two years ago.

According to the UN, the fighting has displaced more than three million people, and more than two thirds of Yemen's population of around 18.8 million people need aid.

More than 7,700 people have been killed and three million displaced in Yemen since March 2015.
42 people, mainly Somali refugees, were killed when a boat transporting them out of Yemen came under air attack off the main Red Sea port of Hodeida.
Human Rights Watch said there was evidence the attack may have come from the coalition and could amount to a war crime.
The UN has described Yemen as the worst humanitarian crisis in the world today.
7468a0046b2ab8f8679e228b85c4726c:
Abdul-Malik al-Houthi said that the Yemeni people are fully ready to sacrifice their lives to preserve their freedom, dignity and independence.
Abdul-Malik al-Houthi described the unity among the Yemeni people as the main factor of resistance in the country.
Abdul-Malik al-Houthi condemned the Saudi attacks on Yemen and said the enemy’s missiles have targeted 'our children'.
Abdul-Malik al-Houthi said the US, Israel and certain world countries have also targeted the Islamic Ummah.
Abdul-Malik al-Houthi said there are amicable ties between Israel and Saudi Arabia, and the two are coordinating their anti-region schemes.
Abdul-Malik al-Houthi said the presence of Riyadh in Yemen is in line with serving Tel Aviv interests.
Abdul-Malik al-Houthi said that violation against Yemen has made the country to achieve good military successes.
Saudi Arabia with the help of nine other Arab countries, except Oman, has been mounting massive attacks on Yemen since March 26, 2015.
A statement by the United Nations human rights office has reported that at least 4,773 civilians have been killed and 8,272 injured during two-year-long attacks on Yemen.
0d8146e3687c5c6c51023ddda36bd332:
Yemeni government troops now control 80% of Yemen's territory, according to President Abd Rabbo Mansour Hadi.
President Hadi said his forces would continue to press on with the offensive on the Iran-backed Al Houthi rebels until they are forced to negotiate.
President Hadi praised Saudi King Salman Bin Abdul Aziz for his decision to enter the war in Yemen on March 26, 2015.
President Hadi said he shared the same concerns with the new US administration about Iran’s designs in the region.
Yemeni forces are making considerable progress along the western coast and outside Sana’a.
Government forces reached the edges of Hesi Salem region, north of the Red Sea town of Mokha after pushing Al Houthis out of the Al Zahari region.
The current offensive in western Yemen was launched in January when hundreds of coalition-backed forces marched from Aden towards strategic locations on Bab Al Mandab strait.
The Al Houthi-controlled city of Hodeidah is the final destination of the offensive.
A girl was killed by an Al Houthi sniper in the eastern part of Taiz, where clashes between rebels and government forces have killed dozens.
07ba97dabd6cc05664e9ca41222ca85c:
Thousands of Yemenis rallied in Sana'a to mark the second anniversary of the Saudi war.
Senior Yemeni officials participated in the demonstration, including Saleh al-Samad, the president of the Supreme Political Council.
Saleh al-Samad praised the nation's firm resistance in the face of the Saudi aggression.
Abdul-Malik Badreddin al-Houthi, the leader of Yemen's Houthi Ansarullah movement, addressed the nation, saying the kingdom's almost daily airstrikes against civilians are nothing short of war crimes.
On March 26, 2015, Saudi Arabia, backed by a number of African and Persian Gulf Arab states, began launching airstrikes on different areas across Yemen.
The campaign has so far left over 12,000 civilians dead, pushing the Arab world's poorest country to the verge of famine.
As the war enters its third year, Saudi Arabia has failed to fulfill its declared goals of war and seems without an exit strategy.
The Saudi intervention in the conflict came months after Yemen's Houthi Ansarullah movement took state matters in its hands after the former president, Abd Rabbuh Mansur Hadi, stepped down and fled to Riyadh.
Several rounds of peace talks between Ansarullah and the Saudi-sponsored party, loyal to Hadi, have failed to yield results amid deep divisions.
The chaos in Yemen, fueled by the Saudi campaign, has given the Takfiri al-Qaeda and Daesh terror groups room to operate in the country.
0d8e556386daa19f638bdf6c8262b578:
Iran may deploy more advanced military capabilities to Yemen to support Al Houthis and former strongman Ali Abdullah Saleh's militia.
Increased Iranian involvement will prolong Yemen's civil war, worsen the humanitarian crisis, and allow Al Qaida in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) to expand its support base.
Iran may increase its engagement in Yemen if US support for the Saudi-led coalition threatens the Al Houthi-Saleh faction's survival.
Iran may attempt to incorporate the Al Houthis into its Axis of Resistance coalition.
Further escalation in the Yemeni civil war will threaten freedom of navigation in the Red Sea, risking global commercial markets and the US Navy's freedom of movement.
Iran had attempted to smuggle over 2,000 small arms into Yemen in 2015 and 2016, in addition to a large stockpile of other weapons.
Iran likely facilitated the development of an Al Houthi-Saleh naval mining program.
Iran provides sophisticated weaponry that allows the Al Houthi-Saleh faction to hold terrain, counter Saudi-led coalition capabilities, and threaten US freedom of movement in the Red Sea.
The Al Houthi-Saleh militias possess a large number of Iran-supplied sophisticated weapons and technological devices, such as unmanned aerial vehicles, the technology for unmanned remote-controlled boat attacks, anti-ship cruise missiles, and anti-tank guided weapons.
Al Houthi-Saleh ballistic missile launches increased in 2017, and Hezbollah or IRGC-QF likely provided technical expertise to modify pre-existing Scud missile stockpiles for longer range capabilities.
90fdda2ad2be29f73388dfd8aa04685f:
Iran has sent advisers from Shiite proxies, including Afghan forces, to train Houthi units and provide logistical support.
The deployment of interoperable proxy forces is part of Iran’s evolution of a form of hybrid warfare that will allow it to project significant force far from its borders and fundamentally alter the balance of power in the region.
Houthi forces are using what appears to be Iranian-supplied drone technology.
Iran and the Houthis are facing off against Saudi Arabia and an Arab coalition, part of a regional power struggle that is also exacerbating the conflict in Syria.
Iran has been accused of supplying the technology that allowed Houthi forces to use a remote-controlled boat to attack a Saudi vessel in the Red Sea last January.
The Houthis, a Zaidi Shiite minority, launched a series of rebellions against the government of Ali Abdullah Saleh in 2004, and forced him from power in 2011 during the Arab Spring.
Government forces in the south and east remain in control of most of Yemen’s territory today, while the Houthis and their allies hold population centres in the northwest, including the capital.
More than 10,000 lives have been claimed by the conflict, which has also pushed Yemen to the brink of famine.
The US is considering offering additional support in the form of intelligence and planning to the Saudi-led coalition as Washington continues its review of Yemen policy.
The US should work to avoid isolating the Houthis and focus on reducing their reliance on Tehran.
Other countries are concerned that Iran is breaching an embargo on supplying weapons to the Houthi movement.
1b8bfdb41bbf9426224bfdcd12e8627e:
Yemen is facing a severe humanitarian crisis, requiring a sustainable cease-fire and cessation of air strikes.
Saudi Arabia's intervention in Yemen is driven by fear of a democratic system threatening its monarchy.
Mindless airstrikes will escalate the situation and engulf the whole area.
Saudi Arabia is not ready for a political solution and wants to finish Houthis first.
External powers must be expelled for a political settlement through negotiations by Yemenis.
Iran denies accusations of arming Houthis and insists on negotiations.
International human rights watchdogs are criticized for ignoring Yemen's humanitarian crisis.
UNICEF reports approximately 370,000 children are on the verge of starvation.
The domestic conflict in Yemen began in 2015 and escalated with Saudi-led intervention.
Saudi Arabia's bombing of civilian areas has been condemned by the international community.
From 2015 to March 2017, 16,200 people were killed in Yemen, including 10,000 civilians.
Millions of Yemenis have been deprived of water, food, and electricity due to the conflict.
a34fb0e0b4072d28573ae2f8eead7e7d:
The Trump administration is considering providing increased US logistical and intelligence support for an Emirati/Saudi coalition military operation to take the Red Sea port of Hodeidah from Yemen’s Houthi rebels.
Proponents of the operation say it could pressure the Houthis into agreeing to return to the negotiating table, and bolster relations between Washington and Gulf allies.
Critics of the proposal say that if the operation to take the port from the Houthis is successful, it would create a new front line through which it would not be possible to bring food at the needed scale into Sanaa, the capital of 2 million people, and could tip large swaths of the country into famine.
The United Nations special envoy for Yemen, Ismail Ould Cheikh Ahmed, strongly warned against escalating the military conflict.
US Secretary of Defense Jim Mattis proposed the United States provide “limited support” to the UAE-led operation in a memo to national security adviser H.R. McMaster this month.
Former US Ambassador to Yemen Gerald Feierstein said if the coalition could actually take Hodeidah and repair the port, it could potentially facilitate humanitarian access.
Former top USAID official Jeremy Konyndyk said about 70% of all of the food supply to northern Yemen — where most of the population is — goes through the port of Hodeidah.
Former US officials said they were concerned that the Trump administration might be debating decisions on the matter in an interagency group currently dominated by the military, and without senior staff appointed and representing dissenting views from, for instance, USAID, and State Department bureaus less sympathetic to Gulf allies’ points of view.
0cb415438364d5c5bfc3aa669f1e302d:
Two years ago, a tribal conflict in Yemen escalated into a full-scale war after Saudi Arabia intervened.
Two-thirds of Yemen's population is facing starvation.
The United States is assisting the Saudi-led coalition by refueling fighter jets and providing weapons.
Britain and the US have sold $5 billion worth of weapons to Saudi Arabia since the start of the conflict.
The US plans to strengthen its cooperation with Saudi Arabia in the Yemen conflict.
The Houthi rebels are not as heavily influenced by Iran as Saudi Arabian propaganda suggests.
The Houthis have access to weapons from former President Ali Abdullah Saleh's military depots.
The Saudi coalition's blockade of ports has contributed to the severe food shortage in Yemen.
The ongoing military escalation will not lead to peace or a turnaround in the war.
The conflict has benefited terrorist groups such as al Qaeda and the Islamic State.
A national reconciliation conference without prerequisites or outside interference is needed to resolve the conflict.
The region requires a security structure that addresses the concerns of both Saudi Arabia and Iran.
6c1bb212d12594da67d80e875e0d4e68:
California State University Professor Emeritus of Political Science Beau Grosscup criticized President Trump’s decision to escalate the war in Yemen, calling it a sign of confusion in US policymaking.
Grosscup pointed out the contradiction in US policy of supporting Sunni-Saudi-terrorism in Yemen while fighting alongside Shi’a Iran [groups] in Iraq.
Grosscup condemned the US approach to Saudi-Arabia as morally and politically bankrupt, warning that it will provoke a new wave of extremists to strike back at the United States and its allies.
Grosscup warned of the danger of future terrorist attacks against the US and its allies in retaliation for state terrorism.
a28a913f8a78eb9c82eeb230f1ab6d98:
The seizure of Sanaa by the Houthis and former President Ali Abdullah Saleh marked the end of Yemen's peaceful uprising and the beginning of the war.
Iran has been involved in the war from its early stages, considering it a regional war and a geopolitical balance to the conflicts in Syria and Bahrain.
Saudi Arabia and other Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) countries are facing Iran in Yemen, who is fighting via Houthi and pro-Saleh militias.
Missiles fired by the Houthis against Saudi Arabia have proven concerns that Saleh and the Houthis have a missile system that jeopardizes Saudi security.
The war in Yemen is not one between locals, but is funded and plotted by regional forces, with Iran being the foremost among them.
Tehran cannot use Yemen as a base to attack its neighbors without a military response.
Regime-change in Yemen was not a wish or a plan put forward by the GCC countries, but an outcome of the Arab Spring that toppled Saleh.
The only solution to the military coup in Yemen was to respond militarily, after the rebels rejected all international mediation and additional concessions granted to them.
edbc45df8bfa0111feedd244edcd4a4e:
Former General Manager of Al Arabiya News, Abdulrahman al-Rashed, believed the war in Yemen would be long and tough due to factors such as former president Saleh's control of armed forces, the Houthi movement's ties to Iran, lack of central authority, and Yemen's rough terrains.

Saudi Arabia and other Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) countries confronted Iran's use of Houthi and Saleh's forces in Yemen to defend against threats to their security.
Arrests of Iranian military personnel in war zones documented Iran's involvement.

The Yemeni people ousted Saleh and established a new political situation through the Arab Spring, leading to a democratic system and transitional government.
Saleh and the Houthis staged a coup, seized Yemen, and arrested political leaders, rejecting international efforts to resolve the conflict.
Military response became necessary after the rebels insisted on maintaining their arms and control, similar to Hezbollah in Lebanon.
Saudi Arabia and other GCC countries deemed it unacceptable to allow Iran to use Yemen as a base to attack neighboring countries without military confrontation.
3a6519886ed5cbf9cc6e21c252f06a5c:
Arab Coalition Forces intercepted 12 ballistic missiles launched by Houthi militias toward the Yemeni city of Al-Mokha.
The Patriot system intercepted the missiles, which were launched within less than one hour, and prevented the deaths of civilians.

Iran is suspected of having a hand in Syria’s chemical attack just as it is behind the launch of the ballistic missiles on a densely populated Yemeni city of Al-Mokha.

The Yemeni Army has regained two new locations in Hijah Province after a fierce battle with the Houthi militia.
The Yemeni Army foiled an infiltration attempt by the Houthis in the Isailan area.
a5ce86b9810b844f2dfa4645b0d16ffe:
U.S. Defense Secretary Jim Mattis believes a political solution through U.N.-brokered negotiations is needed to resolve the conflict in Yemen.
The United States is considering deepening its role in the Yemen conflict by more directly aiding its Gulf allies, who are fighting Iranian-supported Houthi rebels.
At least 10,000 people have been killed and more than 3 million displaced in the war in Yemen, now in its third year.
The United States backs the Saudi-led coalition which is trying to restore the Aden-based government of Abd Rabbu Mansour Hadi to power.
Seven ceasefires brokered between government and rebel forces by the United Nations have failed while U.N.-backed peace talks have repeatedly broken down.
Saudi Arabia is concerned strategically about Iran, its main rival in a regional power struggle.
The review of possible U.S. assistance to the Saudi-led coalition would come amid evidence that Iran is sending advanced weapons and military advisers to the Houthis.
Increased military support for the Saudi-led coalition could fuel controversy over the air campaign, which has killed a number of civilians and destroyed infrastructure, including hospitals.
Mattis will also be visiting Egypt, Qatar and Israel on a trip which may give clarity on the Trump administration’s tactics in the fight against Islamic State militants and its willingness to use more military power than former President Barack Obama did.
U.S.-backed forces are fighting to retake the Islamic State strongholds of Mosul in Iraq and Raqqa in Syria, and questions remain about what will happen after that and what role other allies such as Saudi Arabia, can play.
7aa18dacf8d326889d6c6ab2839119a4:
U.S. Defence Secretary Jim Mattis visited Saudi Arabia and stated that a political solution through U.N.-brokered negotiations is needed to resolve the conflict in Yemen.
The United States is considering deepening its role in the Yemen conflict by more directly aiding its Gulf allies, who are fighting Iranian-supported Houthi rebels.
At least 10,000 people have been killed and more than 3 million displaced in the war in Yemen.
The United States backs the Saudi-led coalition which is trying to restore the Aden-based government of Abd Rabbu Mansour Hadi to power.
Seven ceasefires brokered between government and rebel forces by the United Nations have failed while U.N.-backed peace talks have repeatedly broken down.
Saudi Arabia is concerned strategically about Iran, its main rival in a regional power struggle.
The review of possible U.S. assistance to the Saudi-led coalition would come amid evidence that Iran is sending advanced weapons and military advisers to the Houthis.
Increased military support for the Saudi-led coalition could fuel controversy over the air campaign, which has killed a number of civilians and destroyed infrastructure, including hospitals.
Mattis will also be visiting Egypt, Qatar and Israel on a trip which may give clarity on the Trump administration's tactics in the fight against Islamic State militants.
ded832426dd22976d370a884d65cec95:
The "deconfliction" hotline between the US and Russia is still operational.
Defense Secretary James Mattis is in the Middle East on a weeklong tour to discuss defeating ISIS in Syria and ending the war in Yemen.
Mattis is scheduled to meet with the Saudi leadership, including King Salman, to discuss the war effort against Islamic State (IS, formerly ISIS/ISIL) and the bloodbath in Yemen.

Saudi Arabia and its regional allies intervened in Yemen's civil war in 2015, siding with the ousted President Abdrabbuh Mansour Hadi and against the Houthi government they claim is backed by Iran.
The US objective is for the crisis to "be put in front of a UN-brokered negotiating team and try to resolve this politically as soon as possible."
Airstrikes have destroyed infrastructure and transport, while coalition ships have repeatedly sunk Yemeni fishing boats, contributing to the famine threatening over 20 million Yemenis.
Mattis is expected to broach the subject with King Salman of Saudi Arabia, a country he described as "a pillar of our security framework for the region and for American interests."
1028f9ac6ce1701abe938e52d5f3dea7:
Saudi-led coalition prioritizes the protection of civilians in Yemen.
The coalition considered a conventional air campaign and ground operation but rejected it due to potential civilian casualties.
The coalition intercepted 47,847 rockets and 48 ballistic missiles fired by Houthi rebels at Saudi territory in two years.
The coalition aims to support legitimacy in Yemen with minimal losses.
The coalition comprises Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, Kuwait, Qatar, United Arab Emirates, Egypt, Jordan, Morocco, and Sudan.
The campaign aims to prevent weapons from reaching Houthi rebels and their allies.
A mine blast killed a Saudi border guard on the border with Yemen.
At least 130 Saudi security forces and civilians have been killed in the conflict since 2015.
The conflict has displaced an estimated three million Yemenis.
bd378de2051733b51d380e5985bf08ad:
The US is already involved in the war in Yemen indirectly, providing intelligence and aerial refueling support for the Saudi-led coalition.

Human rights groups, political analysts and former government officials have broadly condemned the Saudi-led bombing campaign, which began in March 2015, telling Sputnik that the Saudi effort threatens to throw the country into a famine threatening millions of lives.
A group of 55 US representatives urged President Trump to consult with Congress before taking any military action in Yemen.

71c33125405812caf08f965478e00e73:
US Defense Secretary Jim Mattis visited Saudi Arabia and called for an end to Iranian-supplied missiles being fired into Saudi Arabia by the Houthis.

The US is considering deepening its role in the conflict by more directly aiding its Gulf allies, which are fighting Iran-supported Houthi militias.

Mattis met with King Salman and senior Saudi officials to discuss the country's security situation and how to deepen the US-Saudi strategic relationship.
Mattis will also hold talks with top political and military leaders in Egypt, Qatar, Israel and Djibouti during his weeklong trip to the region.
b0eb7f92f6addd76f41ab5630eb6d02e:
Egyptian military killed 18 militants during recent air raids in North Sinai province.
Since the beginning of March, security campaigns in North Sinai have killed at least 30 militants, arrested over 128 suspects over terror-related charges, busted about 300 suspects over different charges, ruined several smuggling tunnels, detonated dozens of explosive devices and seized large amounts of weapons and ammunition.
At least three Egyptian soldiers were killed in Central Sinai's Mount Halal area when their armored vehicle was hit by a roadside bomb in mid-February.
Anti-government terror attacks in Egypt have killed hundreds of policemen and soldiers since the mid-2013 military removal of former Islamist president Mohamed Morsi.
Security campaigns in Sinai have killed hundreds of militants and arrested a similar number of suspects over the past few years.
At least 500 extremely dangerous terrorists have been killed since a massive anti-terror campaign, known as "The Martyr's Right," started in September 2015.
6c477ae0d494e14e225458c1ad27307b:
Egypt's army killed 18 suspected terrorists in airstrikes in North Sinai's Al-Arish, Rafah and Sheikh Zuwayed cities.
Egypt's army arrested 37 suspects in North Sinai.
Egypt's army destroyed two major tunnels south of Rafah, each containing equipment such as electricity cables and oxygen tanks.

85caf6dd836bcfa6255c95623f638ba9:

Police and security forces have been the target of deadly attacks by Islamists in the area.
Sinai’s militants pledged allegiance to Daesh in November 2014, taking the name of Wilayat Sinai.
